+Dami N. While I do think that religion does hold back our scientific 
progress, I do not think that we should approach this by forcing people to 
abandon their beliefs, but rather by adjusting exactly how religions 
preach. I think that certain stories in holy scripture can be said in a way 
similar to that of, say, Aesop's fables, hopefully keeping it open to the 
opinions of theists and otherwise, and hopefully alleviating part of the 
persisting conflict between them.

I think this because, in many cases, theists firmly stand by their beliefs 
as they fullheartedly, you know, believe in it. Epistemological solipsism 
is a perfect example of a non-religious belief that is difficult to prove, 
disprove, convince someone of its falseness, or even comprehend. It 
revolves around the fact that the only way we can prove anything is with 
our senses, beyond which there is no further evidence (even observational 
tools as we use our senses to perceive them too), therefore provoking an 
uncertainty of whether anything actually exists.

It's the same case with theistic religions. God is supposed to be 
incomprehensible for a simple human mind, only speaks in silence through 
chosen "prophets" and is only known after death, of which no one has lived 
to tell the tale (ha ha). In other words, it is a complete waste of time to 
try to convince the 5.8 billion religious people in the world of an absence 
of any metaphysical men. The only time I am perturbed is when it interferes 
with someone else's life negatively and without consent. Otherwise, I get 
along with them fine.

comments.text:
You seem to confuse the concepts of infinity and eternity. Infinity has 
nothing to do with the beginning of the universe. Infinity has to do with 
the dimensions of the universe, so that could not be measured. It is also 
possible to have an infinite universe with a beginning. However, an eternal 
universe, by definition, always existed so that the concept of time loses 
its common meaning. Finally, an eternal universe could have measurable 
dimensions and would therefore not be infinite.

comments.text:
+ExperienceCounts2 I don't think it's stupid at all. By the scientific 
method which is considered by the majority of scientists as the proper way 
to go about conducting science, a hypothesis must be confirmed (or 
falsified) by experimental data. For anything which absolutely, logically 
cannot be proven or falsified with physical experimental data, it cannot be 
proven "scientifically" (though that doesn't necessarily mean it exists 
either; it simply means one cannot claim it to have been proven or 
disproven by Science). I cannot see how one could possibly deny my point 
which was that science cannot prove the impossibility (or the possibility, 
for that matter) of "infinity" because infinity is not a scientific 
concept! It's a mathematical concept, it's a philosophical concept, and 
it's a religious concept, but it isn't scientific. And science CANNOT deal 
with things that cannot be dealt with by science, that is, things which are 
not under scientific laws (that is, if they do exist, would not be under 
scientific laws). To bring this conversation around to a topic more 
important and a bit less trivial than the existence of "infinity," one may 
argue in a similar fashion about the proving or disproving of the existence 
of God—it cannot be dealt with in a scientific manner because, logically, 
if God were to exist (I know you don't believe that, but just use your 
imagination for a second here), he would be above science, for he would be 
the Creator of science. Therefore, any rational person can see how science 
cannot possibly "prove" or "disprove" the existence of God or any other 
thing, idea, concept, entity, etc. that, if it were to exist, would be 
above scientific laws.
comments.author: Cork Top

+Soulless34 There is nothing logically impossible about an infinity. A Koch 
snowflake is not a logically impossible thing, any little kid can draw one. 
It has an infinitely long boundary surrounding a finite space. The set of 
integers is infinite, integers are not a "logical impossibility." 
Infinities can be compared, the infinity of odd integers is less dense than 
the infinity of all integers. Not a logical impossibility.

The only things that are logically impossible is for an invisible, 
supernatural being to conjure the universe from nothing. You can't have an 
infinite something and nothing at the same time. Magic and the supernatural 
only exist in fairy tales, they do not occur in the natural world, and it's

comments.text:
+Cork Top  Actually, ExperienceCounts2 is right, infinity is a concept that 
explains something that is logically impossible. The concept itself is 
logically possible, but all that means is that it is logical to give a 
definition of this concept to the word "infinity". Infinity is impossible 
to actually have because it is something that is never ending. I can't have 
an infinite amount of apples because infinity isn't countable because its 
never ending, but I can count every apple that I have. It would be 
impossible to count every apple I had if I had an infinite amount of apples 
because no matter how high I count, there is still going to be another 
apple. Therefore, infinity is logically impossible. This contradicts itself 
because if that time were infinite, that is logically impossible (from a 
non-Atheist point of view). If God made the universe, then God would be 
infinite, but that is logically impossible (from an Atheist point of view). 
Neither can be logically right, but there has to be an explanation to how 
the universe began. There is no logical answer to how the universe began or 
how it got here, but all we know is that it is here; therefore, something 
illogical created the universe.

Ever since men were able to think, they have been wondering what this 
universe really is and how it came to be there. And, very roughly, two 
views have been held. First, there is what is called the materialist view. 
People who take that view think that matter and space just happen to exist, 
and always have existed, nobody knows why; and that the matter, behaving in 
certain fixed ways, has just happened, by a sort of fluke, to produce 
creatures like ourselves who are able to think. By one chance in a thousand 
something hit our sun and made it produce the planets; and by another 
thousandth chance the chemicals necessary for life, and the right 
temperature, occurred on one of these planets, and so some of the matter on 
this earth came alive; and then, by a very long series of chances, the 
living creatures developed into things like us. The other view is the 
religious view. (*) According to it, what is behind the universe is more 
like a mind than it is like anything else we know
That is to say, it is conscious, and has purposes, and prefers one thing to 
another. And on this view it made the universe, partly for purposes we do 
not know, but partly, at any rate, in order to produce creatures like 
itself—I mean, like itself to the extent of having minds. Please do not 
think that one of these views was held a long time ago and that the other 
has gradually taken its place. Wherever there have been thinking men both 
views turn up. And note this too. You cannot find out which view is the 
right one by science in the ordinary sense. Science works by experiments. 
It watches how things behave. Every scientific statement in the long run, 
however complicated it looks, really means something like, "I pointed the 
telescope to such and such a part of the sky at 2:20 A.M. on January 15th 
and saw so-and-so," or, "I put some of this stuff in a pot and heated it to 
such-and-such a temperature and it did so-and-so." Do not think I am saying 
anything against science: I am only saying what its job is. And the more 
scientific a man is, the more (I believe) he would agree with me that this 
is the job of science—and a very useful and necessary job it is too. But 
why anything comes to be there at all, and whether there is anything behind 
the things science observes—something of a different kind—this is not a 
scientific question. If there is "Something Behind," then either it will 
have to remain altogether unknown to men or else make itself known in some 
different way.﻿
top_comment.author: Johanon Zimmerman

comments.text:
*"If there is "Something Behind," then either it will have to remain 
altogether unknown to men or else make itself known in some different way."*

I think you fail to engage with the fact that most religions make concrete 
claims about how gods manifest in response to ritual magic and that these 
claims are universally falsified. What you're talking about there is 
basically some kind of deism and such ideas are inherently irrational due 
to lacking evidence and being unfalsifiable. It has no more content to say 
that a deist god exists than to say that the universe dribbled out of the 
nose of a transcendental space goat. Both hypotheses are equally probable 
given what we know and you could make up an infinity of others. While we 
can't prove any of them wrong, Occam's razor and the principles of rational 
inference are rather clear on how we should deal with situations like this. 
That would be to tentatively declare Naturalism as the best hypothesis and 
go with that until there's a reason to suppose that what currently appears 
to be unsubstantiated nonsense is actually part of reality.

comments.text:
The universe could merely be a statistical fluke. It's possible - not 
likely, but still possible that all the atoms of oxygen in the room you're 
sitting in could all just happen to end up in one corner of the room. The 
distribution is just statistical, sand it doesn't happen often but if you 
wait an infinite amount of time, it *will* happen. In an infinite amount of 
time, it also *will* happen that all the oxygen atoms congregate in your 
left ear... and all of them will line up along a perfectly straight line... 
and that will happen at least once for each possible direction for a 
line... ad infinitum (did I just make that pun? Bad Dan! No doughnut!)

So given an infinite amount of time it's entirely possible that all the 
matter in the entire universe just happened to end up at a single point. If 
you wait an infinite amount of time, then that eventually *will* happen.

At least it's a probability that can be calculated... I haven't seen too 
many apologists offering calculations for the odds of the gods randomly 
forming from supernatural fluff and pixie dust.
comments.author: ExperienceCounts2

top_comment.author: Adam Wojtczak

comments.text:
Einstein put a fudge factor (the cosmological constant) into his equation 
for general relativity in order to keep the universe static.  Some 
scientists worked on solving his equations without the cosmological 
constant and found that the universe could be expanding.

Georges Lemaitre was not the first to propose an expanding, or otherwise 
non-static, universe based on solutions to Einstein’s equation for general 
relativity: Alexander Friedman was.   Friedman died in 1925 (so he must 
have published before then), whereas Lemaitre didn’t publish his work until 
1927.  Both works went almost completely unknown until Hubble’s discovery 
of expansion.

comments.text:
+Cozmolyne Obvious, isn't it? Reason tells us that the natural world is 
consistent. It isn't gravity that keeps us on the ground in place on Earth 
but invisible gnomes holding on to our feet in another place on Earth.

Superstition (which by definition includes religion - I only add the 
'/religious' because religious people in general are ignorant of that fact) 
holds that anything can happen for no reason at any time.

Distinguish between these claims: only gravity holds us to the Earth vs. 
only electromagnetism holds us to the Earth. They are clearly different 
claims because they are claims about the natural world. There are rational 
(consistent) rules at work in the natural world.

Now distinguish between these claims: only the will of Thor holds us to the 
Earth vs. only the will of the Easter Bunny holds us to the Earth. Are they 
different claims?

There is no possible way to reason about claims of the supernatural. Are 
they different? No one can say. Are they contradictory? No one can say. Is 
one of those claims true on Thursdays but false on the other days of the 
week? No one can say, because no one has ever found any rules or reasons 
associated with the supernatural world.

Superstition and the supernatural are just different names for one giant 
steaming vat of anti-rational shit that people present as their warrant 
when they are unable (or unwilling) to accept that reason works.

If there are no rules, then reason can never be apply. The closest anyone 
has ever gotten to actually reasoning about the supernatural world were the 
attempts to measure the length of angel's wings and to count how many of 
them could sit on the head of a pin.


Imagine where the world might be if those ignorant cretins had spent all 
that utterly wasted time considering where diseases and infections came 
from. Imagine if Buddhist monks spent decades pondering cell formation 
instead of selfishly pursuing their own personal experiences. Imagine if 
the Catholic church spent its billions on a cure for cancer instead of 
using it to cause death and misery by blocking family planning, stem cell 
research and the distribution of condoms. Imagine if the trillions of 
dollars wasted on psychic hotlines, horoscopes, palm reading and tarot 
cards were focused instead on solving the problems of homelessness and 
hunger. What if all the person-hours wasted removing the 13th floor from 
tall buildings or changing addresses so no ones house number was 666 were 
instead spent pondering ways to make construction or city services more 
efficient?

Those are real world examples of superstition and the rejection of reason 
are one and the same.

They're the low hanging fruit, but I honestly can't think of a single 
subtle case where adopting superstition isn't a blatant rejection of 
reason. As soon as one accepts "Maybe cancer starts because the gods are 
angry" then I can see no possible path to reason after that point other 
than simply returning to the starting point and accepting that reason works 
and unreason doesn't.

There is also the fact that reason identifies cause, whereas superstition 
can only postpone identifying cause.

Reason supports the extremely counter-intuitive evidence that quantum 
theory and the big bang are correct. All the bizarre behaviour at the 
subatomic level, all of the unimaginable temperatures and pressures present 
at the time of the big bang, they were all established using reason and 
they can all be confirmed using reason, because reason can identify false 
reasoning. If it contradicts all the available evidence, then it is false 
reasoning.

Superstition cannot identify cause because it's fundamentally opposed to 
reason. Superstition can't identify false unreasoning. Superstition, rather 
than eliminating the false, simply splits into additional superstitions 
whenever it encounters a contradiction.

Again, there is no path back to reality. You can say "maybe telekinesis 
involves an undetected energy... and since this contradicts 
renormalization, maybe it involves an undetected energy to which 
renormalization doesn't apply... and since that flies in the face of the 
standard model then maybe it involves an energy that is outside the domain 
of renormalization and outside the domain of the standard model... and 
since that would defy our understanding of space-time...  At no point does 
superstition ever arrive at "enough is enough, stop the bullshit."

Superstition cannot allow reason to be applied, because that would cause 
the collapse of the entire chain of claims no matter where in that chain 
you apply it. As soon as you apply reason and say "There isn't any evidence 
of anything outside the bounds of renormalization" then the entire chain 
collapses.

If you jump in the middle of the chain and apply reason e.g. "the standard 
model is incomplete but there's no evidence that one of the missing parts 
is a type of energy strong enough to interact with matter" then the whole 
chain logically collapses - though from a superstitious perspective that's 
not a problem as it one can just postulate more superstitions.

If you go straight to the end of the chain and say "There's no indication 
that our understanding of cosmology is so faulty that an energy of the 
magnitude required would not be detected at all" then once again the whole 
chain of superstitions collapses because the same reasoning can be applied 
at every bifurcation of the superstition tree.

Actually that's probably a good way to think about it - science starts with 
facts on the ground and tests claims against those facts in order to build 
those roots into a solid trunk of theory, whereas superstition starts with 
a single claim arbitrarily selected from that trunk and from there splits 
infinitely many times, leafing each time it collides with the newly 
acquired evidence.

Superstitions can't converge on a single truth because new superstitions 
must always be created as a reaction to new evidence. More facts = more 
superstitious rationalization. Science converges on a single truth because 
reason (Occam's razor in this case) inhibits divergence. More facts = fewer 
scientific theories.

An Neil Turok likes to show on his slides, the proof that we understand 
most of what happens in the observable universe fits on a single page - 
even if printed on a single line on a single page, it's still readable.

Meanwhile tens of thousands of years of accumulated "wisdom" from the 
superstitious crowd, millions of written pages and yet they can't even 
agree with each other on what constitutes evidence for supernatural beings 
or supernatural forces.

Reason says that after all that time they should have been able to make at 
least *some* miniscule bit of progress towards explaining whatever the fuck 
it is they're babbling about. Since they haven't made any, it's safe to say 
it that such beliefs aren't just contrary to reason, they're actively 
hostile to it.

comments.text:
We have proof and a foundation upon which maths is set to say that the big 
bang (or crunch, or even big bounce) happened. And, it is said that there 
must be more than one universe: a metaverse, in fact. Our universe might be 
really, really big — but finite. Or it might be infinitely big.

Both cases, says physicist Brian Greene, are possibilities, but if the 
latter is true, so is another posit: There are only so many ways matter can 
arrange itself within that infinite universe. Eventually, matter has to 
repeat itself and arrange itself in similar ways. So if the universe is 
infinitely large, it is also home to infinite parallel universes.

Does that sound confusing? Try this:

Think of the universe like a deck of cards.

"Now, if you shuffle that deck, there's just so many orderings that can 
happen," Greene says. "If you shuffle that deck enough times, the orders 
will have to repeat. Similarly, with an infinite universe and only a finite 
number of complexions of matter, the way in which matter arranges itself 
has to repeat."


Other than that stuff though.... we know so little.. So, what happened to

comments.text:
+luispihormiguero2 By definition an infinite amount of time can't finish 
passing. Time keeps going, as one can clearly see. Therefore it's safe to 
assume that the universe either had a beginning or has existed for 
eternity. In the end of the video the guy said that scientists are finding 
evidence that the universe may be eternal.

As for probabilities, they're really only valid in a situation where time 
is limited. For practical reasons we like to think that time is limited 
when we make probability calculations. However, in a universe where time is 
not limited the probability of everything is 1, because the fundamental 
factor that could stop something from happening, the lack of time, doesn't 
exist. Sooner or later it's going to happen. Or, as you point out, the 
probability could just as well be 0. It could also be a superposition where 
it's 1 and 0 at the same time. In any case we really have very little idea 
of what to expect.

comments.author: ExperienceCounts2

comments.text:
+Steven Sell "You make statements like, "You have to be able to perform a 
controlled test.."

By what authority are those statements being issued?" - If we want to be 
able to verify what we believe to be true, only by putting our ideas to the 
test will we be able to do that. There is no authority. How else can we 
ever come to any conclusions about how the universe works without putting 
our ideas to the test?

"You see, I think the debate between empiricists and 'mystics', ... is more 
complicated than most initially assume." - I would disagree. I would 
actually pose that we have created a problem where there isn't a problem. 
We have complicated things more than needed.

We have invented this "realm" that supposedly exists beyond the "natural" 
world (supernatural) when that in itself, is something we could never have 
known to exist. The way in which we have defined the supernatural tells me 
it doesn't exist and we can never know if it exists - In order to construct 
an idea within our mind about the universe, we would need to have had 
observed, experienced, sensed or measured a phenomenon - but by the very 
definition of the supernatural, we cannot observe, experience, sense or 
measure using any tool so therefore, the only conclusion I can come to is 
that it is merely a label we have used when we are unable to explain an 
event. 

It is merely the label we use when we cannot explain things. Other labels 
include the paranormal, mystic, magic etc. - all of these labels are used 
when we cannot explain a certain phenomenon about the reality in which we 
experience. And in every case where we attached these labels for certain 
events, we have always been able to explain it by natural means and there 
was never anything "beyond the natural world" required to explain them. 

So why should I change my mind and assume that there is an actual 
"supernatural" realm when the idea itself is a paradox to me? 

"Both individuals are working from completely different worldviews, values, 
and systems of authority." - But when it comes to the reality, there is a 
way in which the universe works and there are ways in which it doesn't. And 
regardless of the world views, values, and systems of authorities that the 
individuals employ, this doesn't change that basic fact about our 
experience. Do you not agree?

"You say that an individual must produce repeatable and controlled proof to 
verify a belief of his." - It is much more complicated than that but on a 
very basic level, yes. We cannot ever "confirm" our belief. We can never 
know if we are completely absolutely right about something. We can only 
ever know when we are wrong. But we can conduct tests that show us when we 
are wrong. And by a process of elimination, we can observe that the data we 
collect (through experimentation), will start to point towards a particular 
truth about the universe. We then start to form a theory about that truth. 
We cannot actually "prove" it to be true. But it stands as the best 
explanation, until further experimentation shows us where we went wrong. 

"The individual counters that his belief comes from experiential evidence 
which cannot be routinely duplicated or tested, which is of greater value 
to him than objective observable evidence. " - I think we are in 
disagreement of what evidence is. If you experience something, that - 
itself - isn't evidence for anything. You have to construct an hypothesis 
in order to see whether the experience supports your hypothesis. A 
hypothesis being an idea that can be tested. If you have an experience, and 
you think it was [x], you cannot just declare that the experience is 
therefore evidence for [x] without actually testing it can you? You need to 
be able to put your own ideas to the test in order for you to claim that 
the experience is supporting your hypothesis (your idea). 

So, in other words, if you cannot routinely duplicate your experience, and 
you cannot routinely test your idea about what you think the experience 
was, how can you possibly know that the experience is in support of what 
you think the cause of it was? It comes down to faith - merely what you 
believe it to be. And if you truly want to know about your experiences and 
what the cause of them was, you will depend on being able to replicate the 
experience and experiment and test your hypothesis. 

The process I am trying to explain here is basically the scientific method 
- which is our best method (no doubt) of acquiring knowledge. Now you can 
complicate things as much as you want. But you cannot argue with the fact 
that using the scientific method, we have accomplished things that just 20 
years ago, we would think the technology we have now was alien technology. 
If we go back further, like a thousand years ago, the things we have 
accomplished now would be indistinguishable from magic.
comments.author: Descartes Rene

comments.text:
+Descartes Rene Had a quick question while I was reading your response. 
 You make statements like, "You have to be able to perform a controlled 
test.."

By what authority are those statements being issued?  You see, I think the 
debate between empiricists and 'mystics', if we are going to use that term 
to denote individuals who believe in concepts which are purported to be 
beyond the bounds of our ability to test or observe them in a controlled 
manner, is more complicated than most initially assume.

Both individuals are working from completely different worldviews, values, 
and systems of authority.  You say that an individual must produce 
repeatable and controlled proof to verify a belief of his.  The individual 
counters that his belief comes from experiential evidence which cannot be 
routinely duplicated or tested, which is of greater value to him than 
objective observable evidence.  

His position conflicts with your system of values, so you label his 
argument irrational.  He disagrees.  Both of the worldviews here can 
converge on logic, but since there are other vastly different components, 
you see logic as requiring empirical proof, and others do not.

In order to have a productive dialogue about the concept, both parties must 
have the humility required to recognize the intrinsic worth of another 
thoughtful individual's perceptual framework by which he sees his 
environment, even if they cannot personally comprehend it.
comments.author: Steven Sell

comments.text:
"Religion is largely irrational, but this is not itself a sole reason to 
reject it." - I believe it is.  

"None of our belief systems are completely rational and take leaps of faith 
at many points." - Not really. A belief system is not required. We don't 
have to believe something if there is evidence to suggest it is true - it 
then becomes a matter of interpreting the information correctly - which is 
what the scientific method is for. 

"Belief in the "supernatural"... is something that stems from the mystical 
experience, which may be induced by 40 days of fasting, intense meditation, 
or the ingestion of psychedelic plants." - But this does nothing in support 
for the existence of the supernatural and there is no reason for you to 
insert the word "mystical" here - you are presupposing something before 
experimentation - this will inexorably lead to a biased conclusion. You 
have no idea what the experience is so you conclude you have no idea what 
the experience was - you don't conclude it was mystical just because you 
couldn't explain it - or because it was unusual to your "normal" 
experiences. 

"A naturalist would say that defining something as supernatural is a way of 
safeguarding an objectively unverifiable belief, while the mystic would 
argue that empirical data and Reason work insofar as describing the natural 
world, but God/Absolute Reality/Supernatural can only be known through 
direct experience." - Having a direct experience of something in no way 
verifies your belief in what you think the experience was and what the 
cause of it was - you have to be able to put it to the test under a 
controlled environment in order to verify what you believe about the 
experience. Having an experience is merely having an experience - there is 
nothing special about it or nothing to be gained from it unless you come up 
with a testable idea of what the experience was. 

If I experience [x] and I believe it to be [y] ([y] being a supernatural 
cause), in order to verify that, I would need to put my idea to the test - 
by definition, the supernatural cannot be tested - therefore it is 
impossible to ever "know" that what I believe to be true, is actually true. 
It is merely my belief. And the experience itself cannot be used in support 
for any conclusion derived from the experience - this is completely 
circular. 

And on a further note, a personal experience is the least reliable evidence 
in support for any conclusion because of our innate irrationality and 
biases. We can interpret our experiences however way we want - but to 
actually verify them we need to be able to put them to the test under 
controlled circumstances. Otherwise, anyone can say anything about any 
experience or observation they make but nobody will be able to know what is 
true and what is not. We will be merely exchanging what we believe about 
our experiences with no actual substance to learn from or any truth to be 
gained from them.
comments.author: Descartes Rene

comments.text:
+Descartes Rene Religion is largely irrational, but this is not itself a 
sole reason to reject it. None of our belief systems are completely 
rational and take leaps of faith at many points. Belief in the 
"supernatural" (how I hate that term) is something that stems from the 
mystical experience, which may be induced by 40 days of fasting, intense 
meditation, or the ingestion of psychedelic plants. A naturalist would say 
that defining something as supernatural is a way of safeguarding an 
objectively unverifiable belief, while the mystic would argue that 
empirical data and Reason work insofar as describing the natural world, but 
God/Absolute Reality/Supernatural can only be known through direct 
experience. Of course, we can measure the brain activity during a mystical 
experience, but that would lead us to yet another philosophical fork in the 
road. The naturalist would say, "see, this is what's causing this 
experience!" while the mystic would argue that experience of this reality 
can also be shown in terms of brain activity and would again revert back to 
the previous argument.
comments.author: Fragments Of Unbecoming

comments.text:
+Descartes Rene "The best debate one can have"? Seriously? It's the 21st 
century and the best debate one can have is whether the supernatural 
creatures exist?

I agree with 99.9% of what you say, but the 0.1% I wholeheartedly disagree 
with :\  That people still believe in magic after thousands of years is one 
of the saddest things about humans that I know.

Think about it. Since we came down from the trees, how many mysteries have 
we solved? How to control fire. What fire is. Where do thunder and 
lightning come from. The structure of atoms. Evolution. The fundamental 
structure of matter. Space-time. The extents and age of our universe. 
Millions, possibly billions of mysteries solved and in every single case, 
no matter how long it took to solve, not one of those mysteries turned out 
to have magic as a cause.

And now the best argument to have is whether the latest in a long line of 
millions of claims and millions of excuses from every religion is whether 
the origin of the universe will turn out to be magic or natural?

Naw. The best argument to have IMO is any argument of significance that can 
be settled based on reason and evidence. Religious apologists will NEVER 
give up. Once we know what conditions were like before the big bang, the 
god of the gaps will retreat once again to "before the before the big 
bang", and once science finds out the truth about that event/period, then 
the apologists will retreat to "before the before the before the big bang" 
ad infinitum.

Argument can only be productive when both sides agree what constitutes 
evidence. Religious apologists are dishonest/disingenuous. They constantly 
retreat and constantly redefine what constitutes evidence.

The only response to religious claims of gods, conjuring and magic spells 
is ridicule, IMO.

An example is what Lawrence Krauss points out, that theologians  have 
continuously retreated on what "nothing" is. First it was no visible 
matter, then it was no air, then it was no matter, no air, no radiation. 
Then no matter, no air, no radiation and no fields. Now that we know the 
truth about virtual particles, suddenly they retreat even further into 
insanity and claim that even the quantum vacuum isn't nothing any more.

They can cherry pick and ride on the coat tails of science and redefine 
their claims every single day, but they can never engage in an honest 
argument because they put their claims above any rules of evidence, any 
proofs, and any reason. They will always find new magical arguments to make 
no matter how long rational people engage them.
comments.author: ExperienceCounts2

comments.text:
+Steven Sell Not once did I say to ponder about the existence of such being 
irrational. I said the arguments presented for God are irrational - and the 
definition of God is irrational in my judgement - well - not irrational, 
but inconsistent. Also, the belief in God is irrational by definition. 

The debate about God is, of course, the best debate one can have in my 
judgement. It is the most important question of them all - mainly because 
it deals with what our purpose is - if there exists such a thing. 

But my problem is the popular monotheistic belief in modern day. 
Christianity, Judaism, Islam, etc. the kind of God that is proposed here, 
is a diabolical creature to me. And the very concept of it negates any 
purpose if there is such thing - especially Christianity.

But even after saying all this, it is still rather meaningless to debate 
about the existence of God. Given that we actually had any evidence for 
such being, then there would be a discussion worth having. But since there 
has been nothing in support of anything of any "God-like", it is completely 
useless.  

Throughout history, the definition of God hasn't always been the same - as 
you may know.

But one thing is for sure: In every case where God has been used, it has 
been used at the peak of our ignorance. Whenever we cannot explain 
something, we insert God as the explanation - we have done this all 
throughout history and even the best human mind did it - Isaac Newton. 

When Isaac Newton reached the height of his knowledge, and when the 
calculations of the motions of the heavenly bodies became too complex for 
him, he essentially gave up and said "God must be responsible" - but we 
soon learnt that no God was required - like always, it is physics. 

We once did the same when trying to explain volcanoes, lightning, 
tornadoes, disease etc. the list goes on… 

God is the explanation used for when we don't have an actual explanation. 
That is why currently, it is a popular belief among theists that God was 
the being who made the big bang - bang! The reason for this is because we 
don't have a proper explanation yet. And I predict very much like in EVERY 
case, the explanation for what happened before the big bang will not 
involve God but it will be physics.
comments.author: Descartes Rene

comments.text:
+Descartes Rene Your argument in favor of an infinite regression fallacy 
stems from too course an understanding of the initial argument.  I'm not 
sure if you've tried to straw-man the construct, or you are unaware of it's 
refined form.  The existence of all the things which we observe in the 
physical world is contingent upon an external source from itself.  The 
question of whether it is necessary for the chain of existence to 
eventually run backwards into a non-contingent source of existence is not 
irrational.  Call this "God" if you will.

You are correct in presenting the premise that there is not sufficient 
evidence to rationally conclude the matter beyond any doubt.  That 
statement has no direct relevance to the central thread of this discussion. 
 

I surmise from your comments that you are an empiricist.  I respect that 
position.  However, it appears to me that perhaps your ego is clouding your 
perception of objective logic.  Other basic worldviews besides that one 
have been widely recognized as having a rational basis by which to engage 
discussion in for a very long time.

Consider the rational and logical discussion that has proceeded from our 
examination of question of the existence of God itself.  I understand your 
underlying premises regarding the argument itself, but your assertion that 
the question itself is irrational puzzles me.

Beyond the present evidence of our exchange itself which is contrary to 
your statement, I don't quite see how you are comfortable with the degree 
of confidence you exude against the rationality of questioning the 
existence of God.  You are discounting thousands of brilliant philosophical 
minds which believe the contrary.  It is also slightly ironic that there is 
evidence which exhibits the probability that your screen name refers to one 
of them, but I digress.

Now, I am aware this last presentation strays from the direct logical 
dialogue somewhat, but given the overwhelming capacity that both individual 
and collective minds possess for error, bias, and general fallibility, it 
appears to be prudent to approach concepts with an overwhelming audience in 
support of either side with a degree of humility and open-mindedness, no?

After all, the question is still very much open for rational discourse, 
much like that which we've all partaken in, after thousands of years, which 
is more than can be said of many extremely well-observed, tested, debated, 
and near-unanimously agreed-upon intellectual concepts and constructions 
throughout history.
comments.author: Steven Sell

comments.text:
+Alkene777 I have read every argument there is for God and watched 100s of 
debates. Your argument here, the "first cause" argument isn't logically 
valid - never mind logically sound. Your argument says that everything that 
exists has a cause, the universe exists, therefore the universe has a cause 
- it is called God. But logically, it follows that since God exists, he 
must have a cause also (since you deduced that everything that exists 
"must" have a cause). You get into what is called an "infinite regression". 
You get an infinite amount of causes. 

But then you say "but God has always existed" - with which then you commit 
the logical fallacy of special pleading. Which is you say "everything but 
[x] has a cause" - this is logically fallacious. You cannot just exclude 
God from everything else - there is no rational reason to. If you say 
everything that exists has a cause, then everything that exists has a cause 
- including God. 

Now at this point, you may want to employ the Kalam Cosmological Argument 
for God's existence - which is essentially the same argument that you used 
- but instead of saying "everything that exists has a cause" - you insert 
the word "everything that "begins" to exist has a cause" - you purposely do 
this in order to once again, employ the special pleading fallacy and say 
"but got didn't begin to exist - he always existed - so therefore he 
doesn't need a cause" - which is logically fallacious - never mind 
logically sound. 

So no, you don't have a rational basis for the belief in God. Nobody does 
by definition. All the arguments for God are either a) logically fallacious 
(they contain logical fallacies) or b) logically unsound (they contain 
premises which are not supported by evidence). 

So now I redirect your comment back to you, how about you read the 
responses to the arguments for God - or better, show your evidence for God. 

And once again, no matter how much you try and recover, your analogy of 
dark matter and god are false analogies. We deduced dark matter from our 
observation - there is no observation of the universe that would warrant 
the hypothesis of God because of how we now define God. By definition, 
there is no observation of the universe that would point to the existence 
of God because God is said to be beyond the natural world.
comments.author: Descartes Rene

comments.text:
+Descartes Rene You are making the argument more complex than it is. We 
observe the world to see that there is existence. There is life and that 
life exists because some other thing gave it life. Ex: a child exists 
because their parents had sex, a tree grows from a seed of another tree. 
Even none-life follows this--a waterfall forms because a river cut through. 
The river comes from a lake, the lake from a crater which formed below sea 
level. Everything that we can observe exists because something else existed 
before it.

Therefore something must have caused the first form of existence.. We can 
call that God. It does not matter which God, that is not even a part of the 
argument.

I brought into the example dark matter because we observed a problem that 
did not fit with our understanding of the universe. (like we observe that 
all things get their existence from elsewhere) There was no evidence for 
dark matter--but a lack of something we knew ought to be there based on our 
previous observations of the way the world works. This fact was that the 
mass of galaxies needs to be much greater than what we observed to be there 
in order to "hold together."  It was deemed that the matter must exist 
based on what we know and it was called dark matter.

This is a hypothesis that was made--no evidence yet, but an observation 
that something might be there we can't physically observe.

I am not trying to get you to believe the premise "there is a God," but it 
IS logically founded. You can critique the arguments or reject them or 
subscribe to something else. We observe what we know about the universe and 
can come to different conclusions about what that means. There are several 
logical proofs that indicate the existence of God. You can reject the 
PREMISE, as I said earlier, but you can not deny that it is a RATIONAL 
argument, as in, logic and reason are used to deduce the concept.

Maybe you should try to read a rational argument for God... like here: 
http://rationalwiki.org/wiki/Argument_from_first_cause
comments.author: Alkene777

comments.text: +Descartes Rene Very nicely said.
comments.author: BenTh3reDoneThat

comments.text:
+Alkene777 The existence of God doesn't have a rational basis by 
definition. Not only that, but which God are you talking about? There are 
as many Gods as there are people - because everyone has their own little 
idea of what God is. You also assumed that there exists something beyond 
the physical world - this is inconsistent with reality by definition. There 
is no reason to assume there exists anything other than the physical world. 
You have to demonstrate this - which of course, given you did demonstrate 
the supernatural world, this would contradict the very idea - which is why 
I don't think there exists even such thing in the first place. 

In my opinion, human beings have defined God in such way to exclude him 
from scientific investigation in order to shield their irrational belief in 
him. And it is not only God that people do this - they do it with Ghosts as 
well. If we define God, or Ghosts as beyond the natural world, as you say, 
nobody could prove it wrong - this is not a good thing - to the contrary 
actually. Because this means that despite what is true, people could 
persist in believing in their own beliefs without ever finding what is true 
or false. It is a nonsensical circle. And one would only do this in order 
to never find out that what they believe is false. 

It is also a false analogy to compare dark matter and atoms with god. Dark 
matter has no physical evidence by the way - you are wrong about that. Dark 
matter is merely a label used to describe the extra gravitational effects 
we observe where there is no visible matter - hence the name "Dark" matter. 
And we didn't hypothesise about dark matter before we observed the extra 
gravitational effects. Dark matter came from the observation - not the 
other way round. It is the same for atoms. The idea of atoms, despite our 
inability to observe them directly, came from other indirect observations 
from the natural world ( or world as I would put it - natural is a 
nonsensical word for me - there is nothing but natural to me) . 

There is no observation of the natural world, that warrants the hypothesis 
of God because of the very definition of God. Everything that happens 
within the universe that we observe, could not possibly be of anything 
supernatural because that would be a contradiction. 

This is why it is much more consistent to reject the idea of supernatural 
as being something real from the very start - but this is merely a label 
used to exclude our beliefs from scientific enquiry - because science is 
our best method of acquiring knowledge - and why would one want to put our 
wish-thinking beliefs to the test using our best method of acquiring 
knowledge? To shield there irrational belief - like I said. 

Science is not about presupposing before investigation - to the contrary.
comments.author: Descartes Rene

comments.text:

We can make arguments for the existence of God using our minds...much like

understand (like the existence of dark matter was theorized long before any 
physical evidence cam about...same goes for atoms.)

Imagination cannot reach Him, so as to assign Him quantity. 
Understanding cannot think of Him, so as to give Him shape. 
Senses do not perceive Him, so as to feel Him. 
Hands cannot touch Him, so as to rub against him. 
He does not change into any condition.
He does not pass from one state to another.
Nights and days do not turn him old.
Light and darkness do not alter Him.
It cannot be said that He has a limit or extremity, or end or termination. 
Nor do things control Him so as to raise Him or lower Him.
Not does anything carry Him, so as to bend Him or keep Him erect. 
He is not inside things nor outside them. 
He conveys news, but not with the tongue or voice. 
He listens, but not with the holes of the ears or the organs of hearing. 
He says, but does not utter words. 
He remembers, but does not memorize.
He determines, but not by exercising His mind. 
He loves and approves without any sentimentality (of heart).
He hates and feels angry without any painstaking. 
When He intends to create someone He says ''Be'' and there he is,
but not through a voice that strikes the ears is that called heard. 
His speech is an act of His creation
The foremost in religion is the acknowledgement of Him,
the perfection of acknowledging Him is to testify Him, 
the perfection of testifying him is to believe in His oneness, 
the perfection of believing in His Oneness is to regard him pure,
and the perfection of His purity is to deny Him attributes, 
because every attribute is a proof that it is different from that to which 
it is attributed. 
And everything to which something is attributed is different from the 
attribute.
Thus whoever attaches attributes to God recognizes His like,
and who recognizes His like regards Him two;
and who regards Him two recognizes parts for Him;
and who recognizes parts for Him mistook Him;
and who mistook him pointed at Him;
and who pointed at Him admitted limitations for Him;
and who admitted limitations for Him numbered Him. 
Whoever said ''in what is He?'' held that He is contained;
and whoever said ''on what is He held?'' He is not on something else. 
He is a Being but not through the phenomenon of coming into being. 
He exists but not from non-existence.
He is with everything but not in a physical nearness. 
He is different from everything but not in physical separation. 
He acts but without connotation of movements and instruments.
He sees even when there is none to be looked at from among His creation.
He is only One, such that there is none with whom He may keep company,
or whom He may miss in his absence. 

''We will show them our signs in the universe, and their own selves until 
it becomes manifest to them that this is the truth.''

comments.text:
+Senaneone My friend, you are confusing definitions.  The term theory in 
science holds a very different meaning then the common mans theory.  Even 
dictionary.com and Google define will give multiple different definitions 
of the word.

The conman mans definition of theory is "a supposition or a system of ideas 
intended to explain something." I believe it is this definition you are 
hung up on.  And you are correct to assert that a supposition is subjective 
to to presenter and therefore (potentially) incorrect.

But you also have to keep in mind that theory can mean several other very 
different things.  For example, in Mathematics a theory is actually a set 
of steps that need to be taken in order to solve a problem.  It is neither 
an idea nor an opinion, it's a series of tasks.

Now to the point of argument, a Scientific Theory is "an explanation or 
model based on observation, experimentation, and reasoning, especially one 
that has been tested and confirmed (keywords here. tested and confirmed) as 
a general principle helping to explain and predict natural phenomena." 

Remember that in order to be considered science, an idea must start as a 
hypothesis, be subjected to a battery of tests and experiments designed to 
rule out all other possible explanations while confirming the idea.  It 
then must face peer review by other scientists who's sole mission is to 
debunk the idea.  Only then can that idea reach the status of theory, after 
all known, testable alternatives have been attempted and disprove.  If the 
idea fails at any one step, it does not graduate to theory, rather it 
re-stets to hypothesis.

This method insures that personal bias has little to no influence over the 
idea.

I hope this clears up some things.

Respectfully
comments.author: Jed Shenefelt

comments.text:

+MelodicDM In science a theory is a thoroughly tested and reliable 
explanation of how phenomena are related. So, the Big Bang Theory is a good 
explanation of many physical phenomena. A hypothesis in contrast is an 
educated guess based on some pre-existing body of knowledge: As social 
inequality increases the homicide rate will tend to increase. In sociology 
there are ways to defined inequality, measure the homicide rate, and look 
for statistical correlations between the two phenomena. If a connection is 
found, then the hypothesis is not rejected. This doesn't mean a 
cause-effect relationship exists..

-------------------------------

1) Suppose you are standing in a pitch black room where nothing can be seen.

2) Suppose you've done a lot of research, and your research shows that the 
room *can* be illuminated . . . but *only after* one-hundred dice fall in

comments.text:
This comment fails to understand the definition of the word "faith". Faith 
= Trust/Confidence (google it if you don't believe me!). There is no 
implication that faith isn't based on evidence; that's what is called blind 
faith. This misunderstanding of definition is exploited a lot by 
anti-religious atheists, both deliberately and unknowingly.
An analogy which sums up faith is when someone (a non-aerodynamicist) 
believes that his aeroplane will be able to fly, despite having absolutely 
no clue as to why it can fly. Is he being irrational? Obviously not. 
However he still couldn't explain to anyone why his conclusion (that his 
plane is able to fly) is true. Rather he is just basing his faith in the 
aeroplane on the evidence of all the other successful plane flights he 
knows about.
Similarly the Christian believer cannot fully understand God or why the 
world is how it is if God exists. However based on a lot of other evidence 
he has faith in God (i.e. trusts in God) based other convincing evidence 
that God exists.

Thus the notion that science is all about evidence and religion is all 
about faith is nonsense. Science is about finding explanations for the 
evidence that we have; religion is simply about believing what the evidence 
suggests, and following it to its logical conclusion.

top_comment.text:
Why you can dismiss the supernatural as a cause for anything, including the 
universe:

You get a lot of nitpickers, even among freethinkers. Folks who will follow 
the nth twist and the ten billionth turn of the logical rabbit hole and 
*still* say "well, there might be supernatural beings behind the ten 
billion and first turn in this rabbit hole so we can't say they don't exist"

Rationally speaking, we can dismiss the rabbit hole as causation for 
*anything* without even peeking inside of it and not be in violation of any 
principles of open-mindedness or reason.

Picture two rabbit holes.

From the first hole, called the supernatural, billions of people claim that 
thousands/millions of supernatural things emerge. The Easter Bunny, gods, 
dragons, elves, magic bunnies, faeries, gnomes, telepathic powers, psychic 
powers, witches, wizards, sorcerers, sea monsters, vampires, werewolves and 
every other sort of imaginary creatures and powers supposedly emerge.

But in observing that hole for all of human history, no one has ever 
observed or produced evidence of *anything* actually coming out of it. Not 
so much as a grape seed has ever popped out of that hole.

The other rabbit hole is labeled "Science". Millions of people make 
completely insane claims about what comes out of that one. Absolutely 
incredible tales of different kinds invisible forces, of time that twists 
and bends, claims of invisible dimensions, mind boggling claims that there 
are things that can be magically entangled such that changing the state of 
one will instantaneously change the state of the other, even if there are a 
billion light-years between them. Stories of explosions so big that all of 
human life might be obliterated if one occurred within 100 trillion miles 
of Earth. Batshit crazy stories of bringing dead humans back to life using 
invisible forces, of replacing the hearts, lungs and kidneys of human 
beings in order to keep them alive. Crazy talk, not just about curing 
illness, but of preventing it from happening in the first place.

Out of that hole, things are emerging at an ever increasing rate. The real, 
solid evidence for these stories being true surrounds us, we actually use 
the stories in our radios, televisions, cell phones, GPS, cars, airplanes, 
even in children's toys. The stories about invisible forces are used to 
power our cities and to send rovers to other planets so that we can drive 
creating even *more* fantastic stories about our universe. It's so 
pervasive that the odds are pretty good that you've got a friend or 
neighbors or co-worker who has died and been brought back to life, or who 
has been cured of what used to be a terminal disease, or who has donated an 
organ or received a donated one, or has traveled faster than the speed of 
sound - or otherwise has first-hand experience with any of a million other 
completely fantastic things.

Every claim of something emerging from the first hole, throughout all of 
human history, has eventually turned out to be a mistake, the result of 
human ignorance and fear that trial and error has corrected. The gods and 
devils from that hole that create thunder and lightning? Oops. The 
gods/devils who send the rains? Oops. The gods/devils/giants/trolls who 
create the earthquakes? Oops. The sea monsters? Oops. The dragons? Oops. 
The gods and devils as sources of disease and illness? Oops. Horoscopes? 
Oops. Telepathy? Oops. The answers to those riddles and the solutions to 
our problems, big and small, have always come from the second hole, never 
the first.

So, how long does a reasonable, rational human being have to spend staring 
at that first hole waiting for *something* to come out of it before they 
are granted leave to give up on it? Is it possible that someday a grape 
seed or an elf could pop out of it? Sure, if you're going to be an anal 
bastard about it, just because the first 10 billion turns of that hole 
weren't hiding any elves doesn't mean there aren't elves or gods or magic 
bunnies further down the hole, however at some point all but the most 
terminally stupid human beings have to give up on the claims that "there's 
magic in this hole!" and just admit that it's empty.

That first hole empty! here is *nothing* ever going to emerge from the hole 
labeled "Supernatural." Some people refuse to grow up and deal with that 
like a reasonable adult. They throw tantrums and claim that "my logic 
textbook says you can't say for *sure* that it's empty just because nothing 
has ever emerged from it."

They can nitpick the shit out of the logic, stomp their feet and demand 
that a thousand (or a million or a billion) years staring at a dry hole 
"isn't long enough" to dismiss the possibility of something coming out of 
it, but those of us wearing long pants and trusting in reason and evidence 
*are* able to ignore the first hole and focus on the second with absolutely 
no significant degradation in the quality of our reasoning.

Demanding that we still pay attention to that first hole, is a drag on the 
advance of the human species. The diseases that don't get cured, the life 
enhancing or life saving discoveries that don't get made, those are mostly 
the result of countless people wasting time and human lives by staring at a 
hole that has been empty since the beginning of time, and worse, teaching 
their children to stare into the same hole that has never produced a 
fucking thing.

If you insist that every time an answer isn't immediately available from 
the second hole that we *must* go back to the first hole and expect an 
answer to emerge from there, you're exposing yourself as a fucking idiot 
who doesn't give a shit about human progress. It's not optimistic, it's not 
hopeful, it's just your masochistic desires running wild. You *know* that 
any explanation you dream up based on the expectation that the supernatural 
hole will finally cough out its first real answer will be proven wrong. You 
*know* that the only genuine answers we've ever received in all of human 
history have all come from the second hole. Insisting that we all run over 
and wait for the very first answer to ever come out of the eternally silent 
hole labeled "Supernatural" is nothing but mean-spirited, humanity 
insulting, and complete fucking idiocy.

The answer to "Where did the universe come from" *will* come from 
scientific inquiry. The origin of the universe was *not* magic because 
there is no evidence for magic as a cause of anything. There is no evidence 
that the origin of the universe is beyond our comprehension, it is merely 
outside the bounds of our current knowledge. Offering sacrifices and 
prayers to the gods is *not* going to expand our knowledge to include the 
origin of the universe. Hard work and the sometimes tedious process of 
collecting and evaluating evidence *will* give us an answer.

Anyone who is still staring at that hole called the supernatural deserves 
to be ridiculed, loudly and in public. It doesn't matter which of the gods 
they claim is still hiding in that hole, it doesn't matter what brand of 
"hope" they falsely claim lies in that hole, it doesn't matter *how* 
intimately they claim to know the supernatural world they claim exists 
inside that hole, they're fucking idiots who have never actually delivered 
on anything and it's you, your children and your parents who are losing out 
when you don't tell them to shut the fuck up when they make those claims.

They're wasting time at a time when we don't have any to waste. Our 
population is growing too large, our global climate is at high risk, our 
water supplies are dwindling or polluted, there are people out there who 
haven't got enough to eat, there are millions dying of easily preventable 
diseases, and some reprehensible, irresponsible, irrational sacks of shit 
are *still* telling people that the solution to those problems lies in 
holding hands, chanting to the gods, and waiting for solutions to sprout 
magically from a hole in the ground that has never produced an answer to 
anything in all of human history.

If you give a shit about the human species, then kick those people right 
square in the ass every single fucking time they claim that is the solution 
to *anything.*  We need positive contributions and solutions, not the 
endless negative contributions of the religious/superstitious crowd. We 
need kids raised to respect the achievements of the human species and with 
a desire to expand on them, not yet another generation of groveling 
shitbags all too ready to give credit for our *amazing* accomplishments to 
some mythical gods, gods those people assure us live in that first hole, 
just around the ten billion and first bend...﻿
top_comment.author: ExperienceCounts2

How hard is it to comprehend simple word definitions? Science is the 
process used to understand the natural world. Religion and sorcery are the 
same things, and they're arbitrary cherry picking of claims about creatures 
and processes in the world of the supernatural.

They do not overlap. They do not intersect. The natural world is real and 
it's where we live. The supernatural world is purely imaginary. It's where 
stupid, superstitious people like to pretend they live.

Does religion make specific/precise predictions that can be tested? No. In 
science, a theory that doesn't make specific predictions is untrusted.

Do religious people accept when they are wrong and retract their claims 
when they disagree with the available evidence? No. Scientists do.

Do religious people present formal, testable claims or theories for others 
to examine or else find themselves dismissed as cranks? No. Science 
requires testable claims.

Do religious people expect to be believed just because their authority says 
so? Yes. Science rejects argument from authority and requires everyone 
provide testable evidence.

Do religious people agree on what the fuck it is they're talking about in 
the first place/ No. Science considers only specific claims.

Science is the domain of people seeking knowledge. Religion is the domain 
of morons seeking magical explanations for ordinary or imaginary events.

The scientific process is designed to eliminate errors and dishonesty, and 
scientists who commit frequent errors or who are found to be dishonest are 
shunned and their careers adversely affected.

and fraud because when exposed it means the idiots and the frauds are

There ain't a single fucking thing they share in common. They're not

Buy a fucking dictionary

comments.text:
+flaskis You say "No matter what you say, it's not going to change the fact 
that we in our nature will always search for a higher meaning of our lives. 
That's what always has driven science and that's the fate of having our 
intelligence."

Completely false. Science is unrelated to any "search for a higher 
meaning", nor does any such search fall within the domain of science.

If there is one thing that science has taught us, it's that the universe is 
mostly random and that we and everything around us that we interact with is 
entirely the result of simple laws running their course over long periods 
of time.

You denigrate all of the value and all of the accomplishments of every 
human being when you insist that there must be a "higher meaning." Just 
because you find human love, friendship, sacrifice and achievement to be an 
insufficient reason for existing doesn't mean everyone shares such a 
shallow and narcissistic viewpoint.

If anyone resembles the religious fruitcakes, it would be someone who runs 
from the points made and rather than addressing them advocates censoring of 
the opinions and ideas that they cannot respond to. That's your problem, 
not mine.

Religion is anti-science. Do you not own a dictionary? Look up the freaking 
definitions!

Science is a repeatable process based on the premise that nothing is true 
unless the evidence agrees with it. If the claim being presented doesn't 
agree with nature, then the claim is wrong.

Religion and superstition (two sides of the same coin) are based entirely 
on the belief in the supernatural, not only without evidence but by 
definition the belief must persist *in spite of* any evidence that could 
ever be presented.

Science and religion/superstition cannot co-exist. They detract from each 
other.

What's even more problematic is that science proves that its rules and 
processes work, 24x7, every single fucking day of the week for centuries on 
end. Everything that is good around you, including the health of your 
family, your ability to communicate worldwide, the food on your table, it's 
all due almost entirely to human beings testing their hypothesis by 
comparing their expectations to real-life results.

When the same rules and processes are applied to religion/superstition, 
those beliefs are shown to be completely and utterly pointless wastes of 
time. Not just wrong, not just unhelpful, not just fuckwittery of the worst 
sort, but a complete waste of the time efforts and good will of billions of 
people worldwide.

The more religion/superstition you have, the farther removed from reality 
(science) you become. Religious fundamentalists are as religious as anyone 
can get. How much room for science/reality is there in their world? Only 
enough to build a bomb. "Spiritual" people (i.e. religious people who don't 
want to be called religious people) are the same, the more "spiritual" they 
are, the less room there is for science/reality in their lives - until they 
have a life threatening disease at which point they abandon their fucking 
idiocy and go to a doctor (or just die like idiots, which is fine in my 
book which happens to be titled "The Origin of Species")

Science gave you western medicine, most of which was developed in the last 
two hundred years. In 4M years of humans indulging their childish fantasies 
and imagining that "maybe somewhere out there, magic is real!", what the 
fuck has that contributed to your life today? Name one tangible improvement 
all that fucking daydreaming has made.

The only answers you can come up with are selfish or narcissistic ones. 
"Oh, x makes me feel better about myself" or "Believing in y keeps me from 
having to deal with reality"

Four and a half million fucking years, and the very best that religion and 
philosophy has ever come up with is "treat others like you want to be 
treated". That's pathetic results.

However the same four and a half million fucking years of the daydreams and 
delusions of the "spiritual" crowd, and what in the fuck has that *ever* 
produced other than "Oops, well we thought there was some supernatural 
agency behind event x or process y, but it turns out it was just a) 
chemistry b) electromagnetism c) radiation or d) random chance."

4.5M fucking years looking for "a higher meaning" by all the billions of 
daydreamers that have ever existed and you haven't produced a single 
fucking thing of benefit to the human species. Seems just a tad 
self-indulgent to pretend that anything is ever going to result from that 
effort, doesn't it? It smacks of megalomania to believe that somehow by 
joining a 4.5M year old unbroken chain of pointless, unproductive wishful 
thinking that you're somehow going to contribute something to the species, 
doesn't it?

Meanwhile in less than 300 years science took us from Chinese fireworks to 
landing humans on the moon and rovers on Mars.

You can flag and censor my words, but you can't flag away that reality. 
Science works, it produces an endless stream of benefits for the human 
species, while religion/superstition fails, not just by never producing 
anything of value, but by corrupting the minds and wasting the time of 
people who *could* be applying the scientific process in their lives and in 
their jobs and actually making a difference in the world.

To the degree that you instill a life-long belief in magic in a child's 
mind, you detract from or destroy the opportunity for that kid to be as 
productive/valuable as they might be. One human being, in their own 
lifetime can change the entire world using science (that not hypothetical, 
it has happened, literally hundreds of times) while the cumulative effort 
"to find higher meaning" by the majority of humans for 4.5M years has never 
produced a fucking thing.

I'm glad I pissed you off, because the points/issues that are now stuck in 
your head will not be resolved until *you* resolve them to your own 
satisfaction. If you're satisfied with sweeping them under the spiritual 
carpet then the world is no worse off (even though you personally will be). 
If you can only be satisfied by a resolution based on solid reasoning and 
consistence with the evidence, then everyone benefits.

Better yet, if you actually are a physicist then you should know the

If your gods were divine and knew all about the universe and your magic 
book is their doing, then why the fuck couldn't they write clearly? Are 
they that stupid? Why do they need to be "interpreted" by true believers 
before they can be understood?

Newton expressed seriously complex and very precise ideas. He did it in 
absolutely clear language. He had to describe all of the framework for his 
logic as well as his his actual principles and he still took less than 400 
pages to do it all. No one needs to interpret what Newton meant, his words 
speak for themselves.

Einstein's paper on relativity was only 30 pages long and precisely 
described the motion of everything in the entire universe. His theory made 
precise and unambiguous predictions, some of which took more than 70 years 
before we figured out how to observe/confirm them. In a single year he was 
able to write concise and precise documents that completely revolutionized 
our understanding of the natural world. I doubt all of those papers took 
him even 200 pages.

comments.text:
+braedenG33 Interesting point of view you have, and i respect that, and ill 
certainly look into this Jefferson Bible. As for me,and the way i view 
religion:
I dont like how over time we have come up with names and organizations for 
each and every religion, even the people of the same religion divide 
themselves once they find differences. To me i believe that people should 
stop identifying themselves as this or that (ie; Christian, Hindu, or 
Catholic, Baptist) I think the bible was written in such an abstract form 
in certain areas that we *ourselves*, *individually* should determine what 
they mean, rather than have a man in holy robes tell us what the verses 
*should* mean to us. We pick, choose, and even make our own sides to the 
point where we are all but disconnected from the rest of humanity to the 
point where we begin to think of our group as the "best" group, or the 
"superior" group and ignore all other possibilities and groups. I once 
asked a guy what his religion was if he had one, his answer: "im a human", 
it sounded silly at first but then i realized this was probably the best 
answer I've ever heard when that question was asked. As for me, im an 
Omnist because i believe all religion holds some truth to them, im a 
Christian because I find that lifestyle familiar  and comfortable to me, 
and im agnostic because i truly dont know what lies beyond in its entirety 
and neither does anyone else. And most importantly of all im an 
Individualist, I judge for myself what i believe has truth and what doesnt, 
rather than have someone else tell me what is true and what i should 
believe. I listen to other opinions no matter there view, and respect 
everyone's opinions and lifestyles equally, however when it comes to whats 
true and whats not i think this is something everyone should decide for 
themselves. Some choose religion because it makes them feel comfortable and 
they like it, others do so because they believe it to be absolutely true, 
what ever the reason for an individuals belief, make sure its the one you 
like the most, the one you admire the most, and the one that makes you 
comfortable :)
comments.author: JTelli786

comments.text:
+JTelli786 You sound like a logical, and well thought out theist. Which I 
respect being that I personally consider myself 'in flux' when it comes to 
what I believe. I don't really know if god is real or if religion is 'real' 
because that in and of itself causes contradiction of what is 'real' 
anyway. I would consider myself jewish because I am raised in a jewish home 
with those values, I was Bar Mitzvahed and I am a member of the jewish 
community. I observe jewish holidays and those are great ways to be with 
family and appreciate being with loved ones, and the stories behind them, 
while seemingly impossible (or at least highly improbable), there is 
clearly a message behind them. I do not mean in anyway to sound as though I 
am demeaning the stories of the Torah or Bible or any other religious text 
because I have no right to do so, but they are in a sense, very elaborate 
stories that follow a similar pattern to children's stories, they have a 
central problem that is resolved and a lesson or theme or moral behind it. 
Like in The Boy who cried wolf it describes that lying is wrong and it 
encourages us not to lie, the story of Noah's ark, while a Global flooding 
is highly improbable and there is no way that two of every land-based 
species of all life forms on earth could have fit on a boat that can 
actually float, it still teaches us to have respect to authority in a 
sense. The reason 'god flooded the world' is because people had become 
disrespectful and disobedient to his presumable authority, and they were 
punished on, a perhaps excessively large scale. While I don't adhere to the 
bible as a means of finding my morals, as my moral values have no bearing 
on the existences or truthfulness of any text and more on the way I am 
brought up, and I consider the torah (or any other text) to be used in 
modern times as more of a tool to teach children, and even adults, proper 
moral constructs (granted there are plenty of not so morally just sections 
of the bible, but that's another discussion entirely). So I don't know, nor 
care, for the existence of god or nonexistence of god, because I find moral 
truth within myself, my loved ones, and my upbringing (which is still a 
work in progress at 15). 

Also, for your research, I encourage you to look into the Jefferson Bible. 
If you don't know what it is, it is a rewritten form of the bible that 
explains what the bible teaches without using supernatural or miraculous 
'acts of god'.

same false promises to people. You forget to mention that religion has been

and reassigning credit for what humans do to some ridiculous magical 
invisible gods.

comments.text:
+ExperienceCounts2
 While I sympathize with your view point you are making some categorical 
errors. The Easter Bunny is pretty specific. If you asked me about the 
Christian God, or the Bible god I'd agree with you the evidence is 
overwhelmingly against the existence of that thing. When it comes to Elves 
we have a broader concept, and we would have to define our terms a bit 
however I'd say it's safe to say there are no such things. Still Elves are 
a concept that would likely generate empirical evidence. Gods are not, 
necessarily, in that same category.

There are two basic god ideas, the one that interacts and the one that 
doesn't In the case of the former the idea comes wrapped up with magic 
powers and when you allow magic as a concept all empirical bets are off. 
It's frigging magic. So no empirical evidence can be expected because 
frigging magic. The second kind leaves no evidence because after being the 
prime mover, or first cause, or whatever it takes no further action. It's 
pure philosophy, a thought exercise. Interesting, but not empirical and not 
subject to any kind of physical analysis.

Now if someone comes up to you and says their imaginary friend has powers 
and x will happen if we don't y, well we can test that. All it shows though 
is that said person was delusional or lying.

I find the idea of God (big G) interesting. I would like some aspect of 
myself to survive my physical death, though I am not counting on it. I 
treat the idea as philosophical and when I hear a strict empiricist start 
demanding proof it just seems like well poisoning. There are plenty of 
philosophical arguments against the existence of god, and even more for 
specific ideas and any kind of rules or holy texts. I don't need to say, 
"Show me the evidence" when I know the idea is one which precludes such.

Hypothetically, lets say that there was some empirical evidence of God. How 
could we possibly evaluate it? Any thing which could point to god could 
also point to advanced tech or hallucinogens. The only way to know 
conclusively that there was a god would be to be the god, then you would 
have the faculties to know you were not being deceived.

Second point. Evil. I've done a video on this, but the short version is, 
even with the suffering and the horror of life you can't use it to brand 
god as evil any more than you could brand a engrossing novel or video game 
as evil for bad things that happen there. If we accept the idea of gods, 
then we have bundled up in that mess the notion of souls and alternate 
planes of reality where we are all imortal and to which we no longer 
remember our that side existances. The events of reality then have to be 
judged through the lens that it's not realty reality, just another 
simulation. To do otherwise is to dishonor the idea behind the thought 
experiment.

This brings me back to the idea that we need to know what we are talking 
about before the ideas are dismissed. You can certainly say that gods are 
irrelevant to you, but they and the ideas that spawn them are a big part of 
humanity. If we are ever going to get past the mysticism of our past we 
need to understand the ideas, and their foibles. Failure to do so will just 
lead to the deification of science, or whatever comes next, by the masses.
comments.author: ApostateltsopA
