comments.text:
+Falaile Toromon Alright, so let's set this straight. We did not, nor will 
any professional claim that we ever evolved from "Apes." We evolved from a 
common ancestor between us and the current primates. Primates are still 
around because they aren't the ones who evolved into us.

Evolution happens in populations, not species. One group of the original 
ancestors went off and evolved into ours, and then a group of our ancestors 
broke off to evolve into something else. That leaves the original 
ancestors, our ancestors and another species' ancestor to evolve or split 
into whatever. This is why all primates look similar, but are genetically 
different than all other species. We don't have 300 - 400 different species 
of primates for nothing. Of course, this had to take a while, so it took 
millions of years for this to happen.

comments.text:
+Falaile Toromon Me calm down? You're the one who hiked up your skirt and 
are running screaming from a completely innocuous and very simple question.

Answer the question: What specific criteria do you use to determine which 
gods are real and which are not?

What kind of a disingenuous person would demand specific reasoning from 
everyone else yet refuse to provide even a single reasons to believe his 
own claims?

Seriously folks, does anyone need any clearer example of the fundamental 
dishonesty of religion? All of *you* who just say "well science can't be 
real because I believe otherwise" are just as dishonest as this clown is.

When you can't answer a simple question like "What specific criteria do you 
use to determine what is true and what is false", you have abandoned reason 
and honesty. More importantly you have abandoned the children of today and 
of every generation to come.

In the 21st century pretty much everything you have that is good in your 
life came from scientists and engineers. If you insist that those same 
scientists and engineers are conspiring worldwide just because they 
disagree with some ancient hand-me-down superstitions scribbled down by 
some Iron age semi-primitives, you aren't just being unreasonable you're 
being ridiculous.

Do you have any respect for this clown, a guy so dishonest that he can't 
even acknowledge, let alone answer, a very simple question about his 
beliefs?

So what's different about your beliefs? Can you say specifically what 
criteria you personally use to determine that all cosmologists are fucking 
idiots or conspiring against your beliefs that the gods created the 
universe?

Science is the only method we have for converging on the truth. It's the 
"agile methodology" of  human progress. It's the reason your children 
aren't dead from cholera or the flu or plague. Reason and science are the 
reason daughters are rarely burned at the stake and sons are rarely 
sacrificed on altars anymore.

The gods didn't rescind their demands for human sacrifice and retribution, 
those events are rare because reason and science showed that human 
sacrifice didn't produce better crop yields or end plagues. On the rare 
times they do happen, it's *because* religion is still tolerated.

Why stop human progress now? What happens when your child suffers a spinal 
injury that leaves them permanently disabled where stem cell research 
*might* have provided a treatment for the injury? Religion makes the claim 
that sort of research will make the gods angry. Are you still going to put 
up with primitive idiocy like that when it's your great grandchildren's 
lives they're fucking with? If so, do you really consider it moral to deny 
them treatment because of an ancient superstition that says a clump of 150 
cells has a magical soul?

With what generation will we stop taking "it will anger the gods" as an 
excuse for anything? Why not make it *your* generation that finally puts an 
end to it?

Reason and science will move us forward. We have endless examples of that. 
You can put your hands on multiple pieces of tangible evidence of that 
without even leaving the chair you're sitting in. The screen you're reading 
this on works, doesn't it? We're driving rovers around on Mars, aren't we?

Compare that to religion. Hundreds, maybe thousands of children *RIGHT NOW* 
are starving to death or dying from HIV infections in Africa and other 
places because religious people claim that condoms will make the gods 
angry. Look at Kevin Carter's famous photograph. Study it. Do you really 
want to be a part of the tradition that created the conditions he 
photographed?

You can claim that those aren't your beliefs, that your version of religion 
doesn't do that, but when you argue that everyone has a right to their own 
beliefs, you're complicit. If you assert that no one can make value 
judgements on belief systems then *you* are endorsing that behaviour and 
the behaviour of the 19 Saudis who crashed airplanes into buildings on 9/11.

There is such a thing as right and wrong, If you choose religion over 
reason and science, it's easily demonstrated that you're on the wrong side.

Choose reason. Ask how we know something is true and *demand* a reasonable 
answer to the question. If there isn't a reasonable answer then it's not 
valuable and it's also extremely unlikely to produce any rules or reasoning 
that is valuable.

comments.text:
According to the Borde-Guth-Vilenkin singularity theorem, any universe with 
an average Hubble expansion greater than 0 must have a "boundary". 
(otherwise known as a begging) So space time is not infinite. In addition 
the bouncing universe theorem is woefully deficient in its treatment of the 
concept of entropy. If we had an eternal bouncing universe, the amount of 
entropy would be significantly higher than the relatively low measurable 
entropy in the universe today. This is not possible with an eternal 
bouncing universe. All of this leads to very strong support for a a bounded 
space time (also known as a beginning) vs the infinite universe.

primordial waters has to do with contemporary cosmology.

*"And the heaven, We built it with might, and indeed We are powerful (one 
says āda’l-rajulu or ya’īdu, to mean, ‘he is strong’; and awsa‘a’l-rajulu, 
to mean, ‘he has become capable [dhū sa‘a] and strong’)."*

Would you say that Sahih International's interpretation is revisionist and

about the Qur'an said? If you choose the latter option, what reason have we

*"Have they not ([one may] read a-wa-lam or a-lam) realised, [have they

comments.text:
+ExperienceCounts2 I am flabbergasted. Not many people admit to being a 
bully. 
Quote: "There is no anger involved in any of my posts. Period. Derision is 
not anger." "As for stopping the insults to religion, have you ever heard 
the response 'Not only no, but fuck no?'"
You have, in essence said: I know that I am hurting people, but they 
deserve it and I won't stop. Which is tantamount to admitting your a bully 
with nothing better to do and no respect for the well-being of others.

 Your tacit position that your derision is a method for protecting people 
is inaccurate. You use a false dilemma against anyone who does not want to 
insult the other camp. Your argument is that by not insulting the other 
side, you are allowing them to harm children. This is an especially weak 
argument, because A) Regal290 has already suggested more effective 
alternatives to your method of curbing ignorance B) It’s not clear how 
insults actually stop child molestation C) It’s quite obvious that there 
are many more methods of stopping child molestation, such as careful 
parenting and police work. You have a tandem argument about mental 
molestation (kudos on the rhetoric, by the by), that the children are being 
indoctrinated against the truth. Unfortunately, it's also unclear how 
insults would convince someone to raise their child differently. I suppose 
it’s possible, by creating enough hate, you could initiate an ethnic 
cleansing and destroy the infidels, there by killing/orphaning the children 
to protect them. But at that point I think it’s quite clear the welfare of 
the children was not the point. So your argument that your derision and 
insults are a method of protecting of others seems unmerited.

It follows from this that, lacking alternatives, you either hurt people 
because you enjoy it, or because you believe you must (or both). That you 
must, seems obviously false: it achieves nothing other than hurting them, 
and you have already show some care for the well-being of others in your 
conversations about molestation. Unless you view yourself as an avenger, in 
which case it would be nice to see some evidence that any of the people you 
are attacking have done something worthy or avenging. If that something is 
nothing more than disagreeing with you, then I would fall back to my 
statement about ‘childishness’. It is childish to hurt people for simply 
disagreeing.

In response to your response to me: Sir you are childish at the very moment 
you decide to insult a straw-man, and that is all you are doing. Adults 
fight real battles, against living opponents. But you have made it very 
clear, from your setting up of an obviously simplistic and false version of 
Christian beliefs, that you have no interest in that. You would much rather 
a hollow meaningless victory.

You have inaccurately portrayed a number of elements of the religious life, 
but lets just start with some of the big ones. The circular argument you 
point out ( I believe in Pink Elf because the bible says so, I believe in 
the bible because Pink Elf says so) is ultimately fallacious. The religious 
believe in deities, texts are merely a path. It would be like saying that 
scholars believe in books, when in fact that’s just how they gain access to 
the material they are studying. You point to moral corruption among the 
religious, which is an ad hominem attack. Teacher molestation do not make 
every person through public education worthy of ridicule and derision, and 
do not make the evolution I learned in school false. Bad people in the 
enemy camp do not make their arguments any less valid. 

You use broad, ill fitting, generalizations to refer to all with religious 
beliefs. For example: “These people are molesting children. They are 
diminishing the health and well being of the entire species by molesting 
the minds of children.” This is clearly, and patently, untrue. SOME 
religious people are molesting children. SOME religious people are 
portraying truths inaccurately. But your banal painting of a world where 
every religious person is a monster, is simply not backed by the evidence. 
If that were true, I would be very shocked to find that a Christian nation 
like the USA has laws against child molestation. Would be pretty silly of 
those religious politicians to make laws against what they and many of 
their constituents are doing wouldn't it? Furthermore, the assertion 
ignores and denies the existence of non-religious pedophiles, helping to 
perpetuate myths about sexual abuse and continuing a cycle of lies and 
damage. After all, a child is far more likely to be molested by a relative 
than a anyone else. You're using the victims of sexual assault as pawns in 
your sad little argument. 

And that brings us to the argument from absurdity. Lets play your game. You 
shouldn't believe anything that seems silly when simplified? I go and smash 
my fingers against some buttons every day to change the pictures on a box. 
In exchange, someone presses some other buttons, to tell another person 
that I have papers. I go to the other person to get papers, and give these 
papers to my landlord. She lets me sleep inside a warm box where I keep my 
things, but always needs more papers before she will let me stay there. 
Reduction is the finest form of comedy because human life is ludicrous at 
its very core. This is why the argument is so weak. It has nothing to do 
with which nouns you substitute; a rose would smell as sweet. 

But lets do the noun game too while we're here. Lets say I believe that 
gummy bears come together to form little collectives, and that these 
collectives stick to other gummy bears collectives, which all work together 
and form a big, talking, thinking, feeling thing. Silly, until you 
substitute gummy bears with “Atoms” or “Molecules” and suddenly it 
magically is believable (because it’s true). Words have meanings, and what 
noun you use really does matter. 

One more, tiny note. You seem to posit science as the source of all moral 
reasoning. I may just be reading that into your responses, so please 
correct me if I’m wrong. This has always been a sticky way of doing things. 
Eugenicists have often used a corrupted version of science to stand in as a 
moral guide. This is stupid, because obviously science is a descriptive, 
not a prescriptive, study. While I don’t want to say that you are in the 
same camp, I think that anyone who wants to place science as a moral 
authority should think very carefully about the implications of that 
thought. 

I do not mind strong arguments, and I can certainly take some rough 
housing. But what I don’t like to see is people using invalid argumentation 
to try to push hatred and misinformation on other people. There are already 
enough lies and deception out there, and I really do believe that if you 
use better argumentative methods, you will not only get at the truth more 
fully, but you will also be able to convince others.

P.S. Of course beanie babies are big! you can get a box full of them for a 
dollar at any garage sale! Who doesn't want cheap pillow fort projectiles! 
(Never heard of a salad shooter though, sorry that one is over my head)
comments.author: Lucas Smart

comments.text:
+ExperienceCounts2 Actually, I do know the difference between criticizing 
someone and describing something to someone. To describe is to lay out 
facts and details on the table. Example, "Your book believes that one god 
or another created the universe" (general description of most religions).

To critique someone is to explain in detail why someone's opinion is wrong. 
Example, "Philosophical, mystical books written by mankind have a tendency 
of using abstract and vague language to get across so-called prophetic 
points" (TheMathShaman, his first comment).

Then, let's take it a step forward. An intolerant or boorish critique is a 
critique that not only explains why the viewpoint is wrong, but then goes 
on to explain why the person should feel bad for having ever believed it. 
Example, "You'll be ridiculed as a superstitious idiot with no idea what 
he's talking about. I love that part in your book where stars fall from the 
sky. You've got some real hardcore fucking science." (You.)

You say that if something is obviously wrong, then telling someone why it's 
wrong isn't a critique. That claim, just like the religion that you 
describe as "childish fucking nonsense," is plainly false.

There IS a difference between description and critique--that's not where 
your'e wrong--but you didn't describe it. In your most recent comment (the 
most recent as of this response), you actually described the difference 
between a critique and an intolerant human being.

See, there's nothing wrong with a critique. In fact, I agree with you, and 
I've been stressing that point this entire time: Organized, dogmatic 
religion is obviously false. We get it. The Tooth Fairy and Easter Bunny 
don't exist. Thor didn't make the universe (actually, even in Norse myths, 
he didn't--it was Odin. I get the gist of it, but still. Facts). As far as 
I'm concerned, any religion that follows a book, especially millenia-old 
books, is at LEAST 80% fiction, probably more.

Here's what I would say if presented with a practitioner of Islam: "I don't 
believe you, and here's a detailed explanation of why you're wrong."

Now, here's the difference between you and me. You're gonna love this one. 
Ready? Ok, here's what you would say--actually, what you DID say in your 
first comment: "Here are a multitude of extremely basic, preschool-level 
facts that prove that you're a childish, sexist, infinitely old moron who's 
obsessed with genocidal gods, because you believe in something that's 
obviously wrong."

See the difference? And yet, we both functionally said almost the exact 
same thing.

You and I, we're not so different. We both believe that organized religion 
isn't true. Hell, neither of us believe in a single, sentient being known 
as "God" (I'm making the assumption that you're atheist--just correct me if 
I'm wrong). But people are going to argue against you more, disagree with 
you more, dislike you more, and overall resist your claims more, for the 
sheer fact that when you point something out, from the little that I know 
about you, I can tell that you feel the need to insult someone alongside 
your critique. And maybe that's who you are, someone who insults people 
because they're wrong. Or maybe it isn't who you are, and your views on 
religion are more complex than you've led the internet to believe. If 
that's the case, I strongly recommend you make that clear now, because your 
current representation isn't doing you any favours. 

The way I see it, there are two types of childish.

The first is the one you described: believing in fairy tales, denying 
reality because you like your own world better (actually, Afraz was trying 
to reconcile the two when you shot him down, so not even that swings your 
way), and general disillusionment. Believing in something that most anyone 
can see is false, like an imaginary friend. You are correct. That is 
childish. But it's a nice type of childish, one that I'm sure most people 
went through at some point. Some people are still stuck in it. Some people 
embrace it. It's FUN. It's HAPPY. In most cases--not all, but most--it does 
no one harm. To this child, we gently say that the Easter Bunny isn't real, 
gently tell them the truth, and let them choose to believe you and adapt or 
go on living in their own little world. 

The second type is throwing a tantrum when things aren't all the same. When 
things go wrong, and when things defy what the childish person thinks is 
right, they get defensive. They get irritable. They don't want anything to 
do with the different one, and to prove how different they are, they throw 
a tantrum. This is the child that becomes the bully. The one that becomes 
an oppressor. This is the child that later in life has to surround himself 
with the same people as him, because when something different and wrong 
approaches him, he needs to strike it down, to distance himself from it. To 
show the world that he's the opposite of this weird, messed up thing. To 
this child, we send to his room, punish him, and scold him, because it's 
WRONG to make others feel bad, even when you have the benefit of being 
correct in your assertions.


Please stop insulting religion just for the sake of insulting it. Even if 
it's wrong, you should point it out from an objective, factual standpoint. 
You shouldn't personally insult everyone who practices it.

If you don't like it, stay as far away from it as possible. Ignore those 
who try to talk to you about it, and if they insist on trying to get you to 
believe them, then you gently dissuade them. You don't go on a tirade how 
everyone who goes contrary to the facts of the 21st century is a bumbling 
moron. Just... Let them be. Unless you get personally involved, which is 
your own damn fault, there's no reason it should affect you. Especially 
here on the internet, where instead of sparking this huge, pointless 
debate, you could have downvoted, laughed to yourself, and closed the video.

Good day, sir.
comments.author: Regal290

comments.text:
+Regal290 Criticized? Do you know the difference between description and 
criticism?

Put the claims into simple terms using ordinary words and common language.

What is the essence of the claim?

"A supernatural being performed a magic spell and that's how the universe 
came to be. I know this because I read a book that I believe is magic"

The proper description of that is childish fucking nonsense.

In the 21st century, with all the experience of hundreds of years of 
scientific successes and thousands of years of religious failures, that *is* 
a rational and accurate description of claims that magic are the cause of 
anything.

I would argue that it is not criticism to accurately describe a childish 
nonsense claim as childish nonsense.

It is not a criticism to describe such a claim as childish, because in 
light of the evidence, it *is* clearly childish.

Take the test. Keep the sentences the same except substitute equivalent 
nouns and verbs. If the claim read "The Easter Bunny conjured a magic egg 
that expanded rapidly and became the universe" is the claim childish 
nonsense?

"The Tooth Fairy had a magic tooth that expanded rapidly and became the 
universe" Is that childish nonsense?

Well of course those are childish nonsense claims, those are mythical 
creatures, right?

One more step: Now, substitute the names of other gods in the original 
claim.

"Ganesha cast a magic spell and that's how the universe came to be. I know 
this because I read a book that I believe is magic"

"Thor waved his magic hammer and that's how the universe came to be. I know 
this because I read a book that I believe is magic"

Now even the person who made the childish nonsense claim will agree that 
the claim is childish nonsense, because of *course* it wasn't *those* gods 
who conjured the universe, they're just mythical creatures.

Only the claimant's mythical creatures really exist? Seriously?

Call *that* childish nonsense is not criticism. It is an honest and 
accurate description of those beliefs.

comments.text:
+Gnomefro In other words, yes, yes he will be crucified, in the sense of 
"publicly, severely, and unrelentingly criticized." By YOU. 


Look, I'm on your side of the debate--I believe every word about your 
textual analysis, and I believed it even before you made your comment--but 
if you call someone a cultist for trying to reconcile their beliefs with 
science (even if that's not what the original interpretation meant), and 
generalize to call everyone in that religion an immoral shit-eater, and 
THEN go the next step and say that most practitioners are blowing 
themselves up (the extremist suicide bombers are to Islam as the KKK is to 
Christianity; roughly one percent of practitioners worldwide believe in its 
validity--the entire Istishhad clause itself is a highly debated topic 
among Islamic scholars), no one is going to want to agree with you, even if 
you're right, because they'll look like they're siding with the asshole.

Normally, it's ok to get irritated or angry with religious zealots who try 
to force it down your throat, and it's definitely ok to put those people in 
their place, but that's not what happened here at all. The original comment 
was "Would anyone here hate me if I pointed out that my religion addresses 
this topic?" Hardly an "ancient cultist," to be sure. Not 100% true, mind 
you, since the religion DIDN'T actually address the topic, but it wasn't 
worded in a threatening way. At most, all you know about Afraz at this 
point is that he's Muslim and that he wants to reconcile his religion with 
science.

And then, the response! Oh, the response... Not just you, but EVERYONE! The 
general response has been, "No, I won't hate you for pointing that out, but 
I will despise you and publicly humiliate you for believing in that 
religion to begin with." Of course, by saying that myself, I run the risk 
of generalization, but with you, Alex Anderson, and ExperienceCounts2, I 
think my point gets across for this particular instance just fine. And you 
wanna know the worst part? The very first reply to that original post--the 
VERY FIRST, from TheMathShaman--responded exactly how you did, but in a 
civilized manner, without insulting Afraz or Islam specifically, while 
addressing the general inconsistencies with religion as a whole. WITHOUT 
sounding like a total douche. And yet, despite seeing the issue already 
resolved, you (not you specifically, the general you, as in those who 
openly mock religion) HAD to bring the issue back up, ON A PERSONAL LEVEL. 

You're right about everything you said regarding the interpretations, and I 
personally think you're right about Islam being flat-out incorrect. I don't 
deny a single word of that. But if you add in stuff that has no purpose but 
to insult the religion as a whole, as if Afraz's believing in a single 
irrational belief is a mistake that can never be forgiven, you sound like 
an intolerant human being who doesn't understand that fact that some people 
WANT something to believe in beyond pure science (one of the reasons I'm 
pantheist instead of atheist, actually). Really, that part about 
"thankfully, they're all blowing themselves up" was extremely uncalled for. 
EXTREMELY. Even if, in your eyes, it makes people like Afraz look 
ridiculous to follow what you call driveling nonsense, you don't need to 
get up in front of everyone, point and laugh, and encourage others to do 
the same. At worst, you chuckle a bit at what you perceive to be stupidity, 
and keep on walking.

Seriously, I know this is the internet, people, but can't we just have a 
LITTLE bit of tolerance?

comments.text:
+ExperienceCounts2 At the time of its publishing, only Einstein and 
Eddington understood the theory of general relativity--Eddington even 
denied that there he believe there was a third person that understood it, 
when questioned in an interview--it's not "anyone of reasonable 
intelligence," it would take a physics major, or at least an advanced 
physics student, to understand the theory past the celebrated equation 
"e=mc^2" (which is actually off by a small degree--nothing major, but it's 
not exactly, PERFECTLY right). To a lesser extent, the same is true about 
Newton.

Meaning, religious "idiots," as you call them, aren't idiots. Not even 
close. Even if everything in the BIble, or Qur'an, or Torah, or Dharma (am 
I forgetting anyone?) is completely fucked up (which, not everything is. 
Just a good percentage), that wouldn't make a highly religious person any 
stupider than the average non-religious person.

And for all your analysis, for all the empirical evidence the world as to 
offer... Who's to say that God didn't just point and say "Let there be 
science"?

Don't get me wrong, I don't personally believe in any singular 
deity/deities or higher being that could be called "God" (pantheism, 
anyone?), but you really have no proof that they're wrong, either--God 
can't be proven or disproven, only believed in or not.

Additionally, as for that quote you gave at the beginning, trying to 
exemplify the ludicrousness of holy books, I'd like to make an example out 
of that, to prove a point. So, if you'll just bear with me a little longer, 
I'll explain.

Although it's hard to tell which religious book you're quoting form, since, 
you know, you don't specify which one, but in every instance that I've ever 
seen--Bible, Torah, Qur'an, and their respective commentaries--that 
particular line only refers to the heavens shaking as stars fall from the 
sky. Of course, you scoff at this even still, but even secular minds refer 
to meteorites that enter the atmosphere as shooting stars. Given this, it 
seems extremely unfair to restrict religious types to only actual stars, 
when many atheists aren't willing to make that restriction on themselves. 
Or, even if it does refer to actual stars in the scientific sense, that 
just limits them to condensed masses of hydrogen and helium. And, as most 
people know, it's not impossible for a huge, flaming fireball to drop from 
the sky. Just look at bombs. Or napalm. Or literally anything else that 
explodes violently. Additionally, in any reading I've encountered, It never 
mentions dropping "into oceans" or "being quenched," just dropping. No 
quenching involved. But, even if I just haven't encountered the line you're 
referring to, and you AREN'T misquoting to make yourself seem more credible 
than your opponent (why would someone so against organized religion be 
reading holy books, anyway?), it's a moot point--it need not be waxing 
prophetic, it might be waxing POETIC instead. It might not literally mean a 
huge ball of fire is going to descend from the sky and turn the ocean to 
steam. Don't authors and poets often refer to the sunset as sinking down 
into the ocean, or down into the horizon? And if that's the case, are 
people from a thousand years ago not allowed to write in poetic speech? 
Because in my experience (not an ironclad rule, but from what I've seen), 
the quality and quantity of poetic speech has declined in recent times, not 
increased. It could just mean that one by one, stars in the sky will stop 
shining. And although unlikely, it's not impossible that since supernovas 
will continue in humanity's future, we won't be able to see nearly as many 
stars in the sky remaining, meaning the interpretation isn't "stars will 
drop," but "in the future, there won't be as many stars," a highly 
defensible argument. Plus, the whole point is moot--remember that we aren't 
necessarily dealing with actual stars.

Basically, what that huge block of text you probably just skipped instead 
of reading (and if you did, then don't call me an idiot or something 
similar for insinuating that you didn't, because that would be rude and 
highly uncalled for) says is that your argument isn't "You people are all 
worthless, idiotic, sexist maggots for believing the impossible," but 
rather "You people are all worthless, idiotic, sexist maggots for believing 
in what I think is impossible because the probability that it is true is 
low." 

Something else I'd like to bring up is that it's highly unfair to indict 
88% of the world for believing in organized religion. Unless, of course, 
you were referring only to religious zealots who are just as bad as you 
are, the ones who try to force religion on you as if there was no 
alternative, the same as the atheists who love to insult anyone who ISN"T 
atheist (I know that the majority of atheists aren't like that, but let's 
be honest--the ones who are give the rest a bad name, just like religious 
zealots), in which case you should make that clear and not insult was 
amounts to nine tenths of the world.

One last argument I want to relate is that on a basic level, although an 
extremely well-worded argument could defeat most organized religions (you 
know, an argument with better wording than your angry tirade), that doesn't 
prove you right. See above for the "Let there be science" example. In other 
words, even if they're wrong, you don't get the authority to act as if 
you're right.

Also, one last word to you. Einstein was a devout Jew and Newton was 
Christian, during a time period where Christianity was still accepted as 
near-fact, and he BELIEVED it, too. To them, at least, it wasn't a forced 
choice between "physics exist" and "God exists." And, from a logical 
standpoint, it shouldn't be.

Now, given all the above--and remember that I don't believe in God any more 
than you do...

Still think that religious people are stupid?

comments.text:
+Richyboi123 There are a lot of ways that things slow down in space.
Space is not a perfect vacuum, there are always some particles, especially 
near a solar system. The entire solar system was originally a cloud of 
particles. Most have been collected together by gravity, but there are 
still pieces of all sizes flying around, from subatomic, to meteors and 
comets. These particles are going at high relative velocities, and even 
small ones can affect your speed. 

The sun gives off the solar wind, a stream of charged particles. This 
pushes everything away from the sun, and can have a significant effect on 
small objects. This is what creates a comet's tail.

Gravity has a big effect, and can either speed objects up or slow them 
down. The moon's gravity is causing the earth's rotation to slow down, 
creating a longer day. The earth's gravity is also causing the moon to slow 
down and move further away, creating a longer lunar month.
comments.author: Eric14492

has to be going faster than one further away. The gravitational force is

it. These are the orbital speeds of three planets.

comments.text:
+Richyboi123 Galaxies are not exactly moving away from each other, in the 
ordinary sense, they just appear to. Actually space itself is expanding. 
The classic analogy is the 2 dimensional surface of an expanding balloon. 
Two dots on the balloon are not moving with respect to the surface of the 
balloon they are on, but the distance between them is increasing. This is a 
2 dimensional surface on a three dimensional "space" the balloon. Now think 
about our universe as a 3 dimensional "surface" on an expanding 4 
dimensional space. Our galaxy is not moving with respect to the "surface" 
but the distance between us and distant galaxies is increasing. This is an 
analogy, it doesn't work exactly like that, but it is the easiest way to 
explain it.
comments.author: Eric14492

things the scale of planets. You should be talking about galaxies, not 
planets. Even things as far away as nearby galaxies can be moving towards 
each other. The Large Magellanic Cloud will collide with the Milky Way in a 
few billion years. Distant galaxies will always be moving away. The 
gravitational attraction between them is far to weak to overcome the 
expansion of the universe.

+ExperienceCounts2 No, it's a matter of faith on whether it was a suicide 
or not. It may look like a suicide at the time, but if new evidence is 
found that suggests it was murder, then the assumption that it was a 
suicide is wrong. And that's the same with science and every single 
scientific law. We can't prove any of the laws of science are true, we can 
only gather up evidence and assume that it's true. Back in around 350 B.C., 
the Greek philosopher Aristotle performed tests on whether or not maggots 
spontaneously generated in bread when it had gone bad. After performing 
many tests, his hypothesis became a theory. Many other scientists tested it 
and found positive evidence after many generations so it became a law of 
science.....that is, until in the 1600's, Francesco Redi performed the 
experiments that disproved that law. Every scientist before then accepted 
it as a law, but this guy just disproved it! Therefore, no. We can not 
prove anything with just evidence. We can only preform tests to support the 
theory and until disproven, these laws will remain "laws".

comments.text:
+TJP77 Wow, this exchange spiralled out of control pretty quickly.

Not that I'm blaming you for that. It's embarrassing when the atheist is 
the most rabid fanatic in the room.

Nevertheless, I'd like to reiterate Leonard Zuñiga's argument because he 
was correct and made his points well.

The concept he was championing but did not name is called Scepticism. The 
logic is that we should be sceptical of any claim unless it can be 
supported with evidence. After all, there is an infinite number of possible 
claims that can be made about the world, and if we were open to them all 
then we would have no way to sift the true from the false.

Scepticism is rational, logical and scientific.

The claim of the religious is that there is a creator God. That is the 
claim. And until it can be supported with evidence, then it is rational and 
logical to be sceptical of it. 'No God' is not a claim we need to support - 
it is the default null hypothesis to the 'God' claim.

Moreover, you stated that Christians never claim to know anything for a 
fact - they just claim to have faith. If that is true in your experience 
then you obviously don't get on the internet much. :-) Granted, this CAN be 
a position Christians can take. But a lot of vocal, public Christians 
demand that their faith is true and be taken as fact. That is where the 
problem starts. I don't think I can recall a conversation with a single 
Christian who happily admitted their faith was the evidential equivalent of 
a guess.

Finally, let us just take a moment to consider faith. It is belief in 
something for which we have no evidence. When put in those terms, it's 
clear to see that this is not a good thing! This is the opposite of 
Scepticism. And religion really is one of the last social holdouts which 
champions faith as a virtue. As such, it is thoroughly unscientific in 
nature.

+Kieren Miriah Happily - with a single question. How did Judas die? 

In Matthew 27, he returns the money to the priests (who used it to buy the 
Potter's Field), and went and hanged himself.

In Acts, Judas used the money to buy a field but then died when he fell 
from such a height that his guts burst out upon landing.

Contradictory accounts. Both cannot be true. *At least* one must be wrong. 
Ergo, the Bible contains false information.

Case closed, I think.
comments.author: Richard Hollis

comments.text:
"Expansion" doesn't require a center or an edge. In the infinite hotel 
analogy the population of the hotel grows, but there is no "last" room.

The big bang & expansion of space wasn't an explosion from a single point 
in space moving outwards. That's an explosion rather than an expansion.

The way space expands is like how bread expands in the oven. If the dough 
has raisins in it, as the dough expands you see the raisins move away from 
each other, rather than away from the center. It's a repeatable pattern 
doesn't need a center or edge, it can repeat forever.

If the universe is infinite, then it is currently like an infinitely big 
half-baked loaf of bread, still in the process of expanding.
At the time of the big bang, it was like an infinite amount of raw dough 
that hasn't expanded yet.

It has expanded, but there's no edge to reach.
comments.author: Zazz30

comments.text:
+Zazz30 I'll have a look at that anaology. So what would happen if you

comments.author: Dav star (Davstar)

comments.text:
That's a common misconception of what infinity is. It's completely possible 
for something infinite to get "bigger". Infinity is the lack of a limit, so 
saying that nothing can get bigger is a contradiction. Infinity is more 
like a type of number, than a specific quantity.

You can search youtube for videos of the "hilbert's infinite hotel" 
analogy, which is a good introduction.

comments.text:
The majority of my comment was dedicated to explaining that outside energy 
sources are highly possible.  The point about energy transfer was simply a 
"even if" statement.  The majority of my comment was to point out that it 
is highly likely that we are not a closed system.  There are many 
theoretical ways outside energy can be added, from the multiverse to dark 
energy.

To counteract the second point you made, energy transfer doesn't over come 
entropy it's the result and process through which greater entropy occurs. 
 Because energy transfer from places of higher concentration to places of 
lower concentration is a spontaneous process, no additional energy needs to 
be added for this to occur.  Energy transfer is only no longer possible 
after the highest state of entropy and equilibrium has been obtained, or 
the heat death of the universe.  The current energy transfer is increasing 
total entropy in the universe, it does not require any additional energy to 
occur.  In short, no energy needs to be added and galaxies, solar systems, 
and life are simply the byproduct of the overall universe increasing in 
entropy.  Your statement that outside energy must continuously be added for 
these process to occur would counteract the entire concept of entropy and 
break our current laws of physics in stating that heat transfer is a 
non-spontaneous process.

The only point where you can postulate the need for added energy is the big 
bang, or creation of the universe.   However, as has been previously 
established, the big bang is the point where our laws of physics break down 
and no longer apply.  The statement that energy cannot be created or 
destroyed does not apply to this point in time as it predated our current 
physical model.

Of course, this entire line of argumentation is pointless as we currently 
believe that the universe is not a closed system and there is no reason to 
assume that it is.
comments.author: IngetKant

comments.text:
+IngetKant Simply, where would outside energy come from, finite or 
infinite?  Energy transfer from anything in the Universe is energy 
conservation, and entropic, which is exactly why the lecture I mentioned 
ended on that unanswered question.  For any of the theories to work, 
outside energy not part of the universe must be used.  It was why the

One example he used was similar to your galaxy analogy, allowing for energy 
transfer from one area to another to explain breakdowns in entropy.  But 
the same problem still existed, outside energy needed to be added, and as 
long as the system was gaining energy and thus breaking the laws of 
thermodynamics (2 at least by my count), it worked.  The inherent problem 
was where the finite or infinite Universe was getting the extra energy. 
 His point became moot when early on even he admitted early on that energy 
transfer couldn't overcome entropy on a large or small scale, as that would 
invalidate thermodynamics to say, "It's a law, just not as this moment, but 
in a few minutes it will be again.  You can't play willy-nilly with laws to 
suit your purposes,"   Which is the inherent problem with the added energy, 
localization is simply trying to say the laws of thermodynamics breakdown 
with scale or location.
comments.author: DSC Charabin

comments.text:
If it's not a closed universe then it does not matter if it's finite or 
infinite.  You also have not clarified why the closed universe assumption 
makes sense and is reasonable.

The expansion of the universe is vary clear indicator that our universe is 
NOT a closed system as some undefined physical force (currently named dark 
energy) is putting energy into our universe that counteracts the 
gravitational force of our galaxies.  This could be the case if the 
universe is finite or infinite.  Many modern theories of quantum physics, 
including string theory, also indicate that the universe (and indeed, all 
universes) is an open system.

If anything, the point of the question is that it is very unlikely that we 
live in a closed universe, although not quite impossible.

All that aside, your question is quite easy to answer which is why I find 
your statement somewhat doubtful.  While the over all entropy of a closed 
system will always increase, this is not always true for different parts of 
that system.  In fact, energy transfer from a place of more concentrated 
energy to places of lower concentrated energy is one of the ways that 
higher states of entropy are achieved.

Take for example our galaxy, which is a closed system by our current 
definition.  Despite increasing overall in entropy, there is quite a clear 
transfer of energy from stars to planets as they radiate heat from nuclear 
fission.  This means that despite the Galaxy (and for the most part the 
solar system) being a closed system, and steadily increasing in entropy, 
there is still a clear energy transfer from stars to planets.  It is this 
energy transfer that is largely responsible for life on earth.  Thus, even 
if the universe was a closed universe (either infinite or finite) there 
still easily exist the energy transfer to bring about life.

After the heat death of universe (an estimated 10^100 years from now) and 
maximum entropy has been produced, THEN the statement you are making will 
be true.  However, until then energy transfer can and does happen on a 
regular basis allowing for the creation of galaxies, solar systems, 
planets, and indeed life.
comments.author: IngetKant

The answer is they didn't "suddenly realize" anything.  Sexually 
reproducing members of a species out-competed asexually reproducing members 
of a species and over time became the only member of that species.  And for 
that particular lineage (of which we are a descendant) all would reproduce 
sexually.

It's not conclusively proven and possibly never will be since organisms 
tend to eat other organisms and destroy any physical evidence, but it 
definitely makes more sense and has more explanatory power than "God did 
it!"

comments.text:

That still does not answer my question. I am not talking about intention, 
as in why the eel has electrical discharge. I do not doubt that it 
developed from simpler critters, ultimately from a common ancestor to all 
life, or that natural selection 'fined' that ability for the eel, or any 
other similar species.

Lets take another example. All prokaryotes reproduced asexually, by passing 
down its own genetics down to a daughter cell. Firstly, at which point in 
evolution did it start reproducing sexually? Certainly at a eukaryotic 
stage. Sexual reproduction is much more efficient, because of the effect of 
dominant and recessive genes. The faulty genes of one parent passing down 
to the offspring is canceled out by the superior genes of the other parent. 
This is obviously a clever, intelligent 'idea' and improvement to asexual 
reproduction. But HOW did this implement itself? What caused the DNA in the 
organism to create proteins which determine the shape of the organism to 
have sexual organs? Can it really be a really lucky mutation? What 
determines the path evolution follows?

actually, male and female) that sexual reproduction is more efficient than

have a full understanding of charges, currents, their effects on other 
organisms and so on and implement that understanding into the organism."

This, right here, is the problem with your line of reasoning.  You see 
intention in the results of Evolution where none is needed.  All complex 
forms and biological structures came from slightly simpler forms.  We see 
evidence of many other fish species using electrical current to detect prey 
and in some cases stun them.  There's zero reason to think that just 
because humans were able to figure out an artificial means to generate 
current that it couldn't arise naturally over a long period of time.

It's simply the case that in the past the environment for that particular 
species was conducive to that mutation so through natural selection it 
became the norm for that species.  Just like every other complex biological 
structure we see.

condensation and turbulence of gravitation itself instead of gaseous matter 
as Earth weather consists of.  

Maybe gravitational condensation is the cause of the observed redshift and

comments.text:
+Steve Bennett
You lied about what Paul Davies said in that quote, you spoke about it as 
if he was going to say there's evidence that the laws could have been 
different. But the quote only said there's no evidence to the contrary.

By analogy,
'You said that scientists aren't claiming there's evidence for ghosts, but 
respectfully, that is *exactly* what they are saying!
For example,
"There is absolutely no evidence whatsoever that there are no ghosts" - 
Paul Davies.'

- That's a very direct analogy; speaking as if the quote was going to be a 
scientist saying there *is* evidence for ghosts and my statement was wrong, 
and then giving a quote that only says there's currently no evidence that 
ghosts *don't* exist.

Someone saying there's no evidence a proposition is wrong (the variability 
of the constants) is *not* them saying there is evidence for the 
proposition being true.

Paul Davies saying that we don't have evidence that the laws are determined 
by physical constraints is *not* him saying we do have evidence that the  
constants are variable and could have been otherwise. He would likewise 
make the exact same statement for the position you misrepresented him as 
taking!
*He'd say we also have absolutely no evidence that the constants are 
variable.* (I've read several Davies books.)

Things shouldn't be believed on no evidence, until they are disproved by 
evidence to the contrary!
They should be believed once there's evidence they are true.

The default position for constants in the laws of nature that we don't 
understand isn't to believe they could have been otherwise until we have 
evidence their values are determined by exotic processes.
The default position is to withhold judgement and honestly admit *both* 
angles, that there's absolutely no evidence the constants had to be as they 
are, *and* there's absolutely no evidence the constants could have been 
different. How these constants got their values is in speculation town, and 
you are being dishonest about the scientists you try to speak for.
Saying there's no evidence ghosts don't exist is *not* saying there is 
evidence ghosts do exist, and in the exact same way, saying there's no 
evidence the constants had to be as they are is *not* saying there is 
evidence they could have been different.

comments.text:
Thanks for your reply Luke.  Respectfully, you are incorrect about my 
assumption.

To make my assumption explicit:

Everything that happens is explainable by:

1)  Necessity
2)  Random Chance
3)  Purposeful Design

For example, the way snowflakes form are a combination of 1 and 2.  The 
lattice forms the exact same way, in *all* snowflakes, at the very center 
due to physical necessity (the laws of physics). Each subsequent layer 
continues to follow these same laws-- but at random edges of the preceding 
lattice.

As another example. A card trick is explainable under category 3.  The 
magician shows you your card.  The intricacies of the design can be 
difficult to spot-- but no one thinks their card gets pulled randomly-- nor 
have the laws of physics (or any other laws) necessitated that the card be 
pulled.

Examples from history books, science books, and daily experience itself 
re-affirm this assumption again and again.

So respectfully, to the contrary, I don't actually "assume that the 
constants are determined by random chance in all non-God models."

What I assume is that the physicists are right-- that *physical necessity 
can not account for the physical constants.*

This leaves us with only two options to pick from.
comments.author: Steve Bennett

comments.text:
+Steve Bennett
You assume that the constants are determined by random chance in all 
non-God models. That's a kind of a false dichotomy, or straw man, you are 
building.
The dice being cast was your representation of what people have to believe 
if they don't accept design. That's just not the case.
comments.author: HeyHeyHarmonicaLuke

comments.text:
Suppose you are sitting in a pitch black classroom.  You hear only your 
professors voice say "I am going to cast 100 dice.  If they all land on 6, 
then the lights will turn on and you will be able to empirically observe 
how these dice landed.  If they don't all land on six, then the lights will 
remain off-- and you will never be allowed to observe these dice."

The dice are cast.  The lights turn on.  And sure enough you look to see 
that all one hundred of the dice have landed on 6.

Would you, then, say, "If the dice were different, life as we know it could 
not exist."  Or would you draw the most obvious conclusion: that your 
professor *designed* the dice to fall so that they could be empirically 
observed?


I mean think about it . . . sincerely, deeply.  Reflect on it.  Taste it 
for a bit before spitting it out.

What other arrangements of the cosmological constant (along with the other 
physical constants) could allow the constants themselves to be empirically 
observed?

In other words. . . How else could the dice have fallen so that we could 
observe how they had fallen?

For an answer to that last question, youtube search Leonard Susskind 
(Director of Theoretical Physics at Stanford University) and see his talk 
on, "Is the Universe Fine-Tuned."

My wife's grandmother was never taught to read or write. She could

the numbers. She went shopping using money though. When prices were quite 
stable, she learned that she need one green with blue, small bill, to buy a 
loaf of bread, and get 3 large coins back, for example.

People were involved in trading for longer than they even had a word for 
that occupation. When trading, people always come up with ways to score 
more profit somehow. Customers will want to borrow, sellers will want a 
greater commerce volume. The first written information was probably some 
sort of note of either credit or ownership, where very simply drawn 
information would describe the object and subject of a transaction.

Early writing is actually full of commercial notes. Only when it has 
evolved enough to express more meaning, was it used for purposes like laws

to transfer folklore onto documents, which became written myths, legends, 
gospels.

comments.text:
+Christfreak
I might be able to shed a little more light into this topic. Just an FYI if 
you do not know, radiation and light can be used almost interchangeably, as 
I will be doing.

DISCLAIMER: I'm an engineering student, so I have no expertise in the field 
of cosmology. I just really enjoy learning about the big bang theory and I 
absorb and keep all information I can find. Take this with a grain of salt.

There is this thing out there called the cosmic background radiation. 
Essentially what this is light that is radiating at us, from every single 
possible direction. No matter where you look in the sky, if you search for 
the right frequency, it is there. This radiation has been calculated to 
have originated some 400 000 years after the big bang happened, or just 
over 13 billion years ago. This blanket of radiation is the absolute 
furthest that any observation can go, it completely blocks our view, 
explanation to follow.

Now this radiation is at a intensity and frequency that suggests that all 
that time ago, the universe was incredibly hot. So hot that the radiation 
which the particles emitted could tear atomic nuclei apart. Essentially, 
particles back then were all too hot to form atoms, so before then there 
were no elements whatsoever. The universe consisted of a plasma or soup of 
super-energetic electrons, protons, etc. all flying around, more or less 
independently.

A key thing about this theory, is that as the universe expands, the 
wavelength of light gets stretched as the space it is occupying is also 
stretched. According to Plank's Law, this means that all the emitted 
radiation diminished in intensity over its travel time to reach some place 
in the universe (this is actually how the radiation was dated). The more 
space which was created, the longer the wavelength would be stretched. It 
was only after this critical point in history when the expanding of the 
universe caused the particles to lose enough energy such that the radiation 
would no longer rip the nuclei apart; atoms could form. These atoms were 
mostly hydrogen, a bit of helium and even less of lithium. All other 
elements would then be created in stars which were now physically allowed 
to form.

I said earlier that this is as far back as we can see. The reason for this 
is that back then, every single particle was emitting light, more or less. 
All this radiation was obscuring anything which might have existed; 
everything before then is being enshrouded by the incredible amounts of 
radiation. It's after the 400 000 year mark where the universe essentially 
cleared of this fog, letting us see.

The reason that we can still see this background radiation is that as the 
universe is expanding, the speed of light remains constant throughout. 
Imagine a RC car driving at a constant speed on a treadmill which starts at 
a high speed but then slows down. Initially, the net effect of the car is 
for it to go backwards from a stationary viewpoint, as the treadmill is 
faster. Eventually, once the treadmill is slower than the car, then the car 
can then begin to move forward. Once this stage has been reached, it's just 
a matter of time before the car drives off the end of the treadmill. This 
is exactly what is happening in the universe, though the speed of the 
treadmill is analogous to an expansion of space.

Space is being created between us and the particle which emitted the 
radiation. So even though our position in the universe and the particle may 
have been quite close, space was created in between us at a far greater 
speed than light can travel. It was only after the expansion slowed to 
below light speed that the radiation could make any sort of progress on its 
journey to our viewpoint, at which point it was so distant (and remember 
the expansion is ongoing) that the light took 13 billion years to reach us.

So at this point some 13 billion years ago, the particles which emitted the 
background radiation were already some distance from us. As the light that 
they emitted traveled in our direction, the space was stretched, letting us 
only see the radiation now, at a far lower frequency (and hence energy) 
than when it was created due to the wavelength stretching. Currently it is 
residing in the microwave range, around 160GHz (as a reference, visible 
light is between 400 and 800THz, much larger and more energetic than the 
background radiation).

I think I might have overkilled this a little bit, I just get really 
enthusiastic when I explain this theory, whether or not they asked for an 
explanation :P
comments.author: Graham Rigby

comments.text:

hot, dense state of the early universe.

comments.text:
+Machiel Sterenborg If I understand it correctly, some of the elements 
could not have been formed through ordinary stellar processes and must have 
come from the big bang itself. There's apparently way too much helium (and 
too much lithium and possibly other elements, my aging brain tends to leak) 
to be explained simply by fusion and supernovae and such. Those excesses 
fit the big bang model which predicts the relative abundances that have

There is a lot more to life. There is a whole lot more that can be left

learning today. Beethoven died 500 years ago, yet everybody knows who he 
was, because his feelings expressed through artistic creation live on far

are the lives of a billion of people worldwide. Bill Gates changed the way 
we share information, and is now saving millions of other lives. He is 
still alive, and full of life. His legacy will live on 
On the other end - there is a single man, that lived in Italy, about 700 
years ago. Nobody knows his name, nor do they know what he did for a 
living. But he had sex, and he had children. His legacy, is that ~15% of 
the population of Europe are his descendants. that have migrated to the 
Americas and Australia. The fact that he lived, had sex, and made children, 
had the effect that so many centuries after that, we have found a way to 
better fight HIV.

comments.text:
+alhr679 Zeno's paradox is convergent, i.e. finite, not infinite. It's a 
seeming paradox because this is counterintuitive. The "infinite" series, 
1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8 + 1/16...= 1, not one minus epsilon. From zero to 1 second 
is not infinite, it's 1 full second, i.e. finite. 
Joseph Rodgers is quite correct. If the universe were infinitely old, then 
infinitely long ago plus a positive one trillion years would still be 
infinitely long ago. The present would never occur, much less the future. 
What's the answer to this "paradox"? It's that time and infinity are 
diametric opposites. Time MUST be finite because it progresses, if you 
will, one unit at a time in a very real sense, and infinity does not. That 
is, infinity + 8 million = infinity, not infinity and 8million. Infinity is 
not a number, so it doesn't behave like a number. It is an unreal concept, 
like ratios. Pi "goes on forever", but there is no existential pi, Pi is a 
ratio, not an actual length. The diameter of a circle is finite. The 
circumference of that same circle is finite, but the ratio is infinite and 
a transcendental number to boot, but the ratio is merely an unreal concept, 
an idea that does not exist in reality. *There are no existential 
infinities.* This is because everything that exists has duration, i.e. 
occurs in time, and time is finite by it's very nature.
comments.author: LucisFerre1

comments.text:
+Joseph Rogers "The universe can't be infinite, not in time anyway.  If the 
universe had been around for an infinite amount of time, then today would 
have never come.  There would be an infinite stretch of time before today, 
and nothing infinite can be crossed.  The very concept of infinite time is 
logically unsound."

Thats not true. It's like how you can count seconds, the seconds are 
passing by, but you can take one second and cut it in half, and then cut 
that half second in half, and keep cutting it in half an infinite number of 
times but just because there are an infinite number of units of time inside 
every second doesn't mean time doesn't move on. You will get to the next 
second and then the next. Another example is if your ten feet away from me 
and i try to walk towards you, i have to get half way first, five feet 
away, then i have to get half way from there, two and a half feet. I would 
have to cross an infinite number of halfs before i could get to you, but i 
could probably do it in just a couple of seconds. Even though id have to 
cross an infinity to get to you i would still get to you. I remember he 
made a video about how not all infinities are created equal. I recommend 
you look it up.

I already stated that language was not the same thing probability wise -"I

evidence that we are on the right track.

"It is far more probable for an entire sentence to be carved in rock by 
chance in the comic sans font with proper capitals and punctuation than for 
the chance of everything coming from nothing."

well yes, but i think that the latter is common misconception. the universe 
never came from nothing. it was just there. There are places and things in 
this universe where the definition of time changes. for example: a photon 
does not experience time from it's own percpective; it is born the exact 
instant it dies, so to speak. Get too close to a black hole that is big 
enough and stars will be born and die before it swallows you up. The theory 
of the bi bang is a similar situation; when all that energy is compacted 
like that(much in the way of a black hole), time does not exist in the same 
way we usually view it.

"Similarly the odds of everything going perfectly to provide life for our 
planet is extremely low."

Again true, but considering we probably have more planets in the sky than 
we do stars, that gives life the advantage. A lot of people underestimate 
just how huge the universe is; we can't even see all of it.

+Wulframm Rolf No the logic with the language thing is not the same.  It is 
far more probable for an entire sentence to be carved in rock by chance in 
the comic sans font with proper capitals and punctuation than for the 
chance of everything coming from nothing.   And that excludes LIFE coming 
from non-life.  The thing about probabilities is that it is the chance 
something will happen.  For instance there is a 1 out of 6 chance of 
rolling a 3 on a six sided die, if it isn't a 3 then that probability is 
gone forever.  Similarly the odds of everything going perfectly to provide 
life for our planet is extremely low.  There was only one shot to do it 
like the throw of the dice.  People think probability means eventually it 
could happen.. no.  If earth was formed a little closer to the sun we would 
burn, too far we would freeze.  The atmosphere has just the right 
combination of elements.  The tilt is perfect.....   Any of those could be 
different and we wouldn't be here.

comments.author: Philip Seitz

comments.text:
Carbon dating, like anything else, has its limits.  Marine life is a good 
example.  Land plants and animals get their carbon from the air, but the 
marine life get theirs from carbonate rock.  Land animals that eat marine 
life have the same problem as they ingest the carbon from the marine life 
they eat.  Carbon dating also fails in accuracy for dating things over 
about 50.000 years as the carbon has gone through many half-lives. 
 Dinosaur bones, for example, will have little to no carbon at all.  For 
these types of things carbon dating is not used.  There are numerous types 
of radiometric dating methods that can be used that are much more accurate. 
 The key is to use the proper method for what you're dating, i.e. the right 
tool for the job at hand.  Radiometric dating places the Earth at about 
4.54 billion years old, not carbon dating.  I hope this helps you.
comments.author: Matthew Harrison

comments.text:
+Linke Smith If you discover a sealed black box that has lights on it that 
flash in a random pattern, do you look at it and declare that because they 
flashed in the specific random order that they did, there could be an 
extremely complex supernatural being/process going on inside the box?

Or do you simply assume that just like *every* mystery ever solved by human 
beings, there is some simple and perfectly natural bit of physics at work 
inside the box?

What are the odds that the origin of the universe is any different?

We already know that virtual particles of almost infinite mass can 
spontaneously appear, as long as they also disappear in an almost 
infinitely short period of time. The idea of random fluctuations in empty 
space-time producing something physical isn't just conceptual, it's a fact. 
We know it really happens.

Likewise if a universe can also spontaneously appear from Nothing, there is 
no rational reason to believe or pretend that some supernatural was at 
work. Based on overwhelming evidence throughout all of human experience, 
the only rational explanation/expectation is that it is a purely natural 
process that we simply haven't identified yet.

As for the fine tuning argument, I think it's basically just primitive 
numerology. "Oh well if gravity wasn't this value and Planck's constant 
wasn't that particular value then..."  There is no evidence that they are 
in any way related, nor is there any evidence that there are no limits on 
the values they can take.

Again, there are trillions upon trillions of virtual particles 
spontaneously appearing in what,until recently,  everyone would call 
completely empty space.

There isn't any reason to believe that universes couldn't behave in a 
similar fashion. Consider Hawking radiation, where a virtual particle pair 
popping into existence close to the event horizon of a black hole can 
result in one virtual particle becoming a real particle, and the other 
being lost beyond the event horizon. Of all the uncountable number of 
virtual particles that have popped into existence, only those particular 
particles become real. Why? Random chance. They just happened to appear 
near the event horizon. There was nothing supernatural involved.

So why would anyone assume the supernatural was involved if an uncountable 
number of causally disconnected universes are popping into existence all 
the time and some just happen to randomly encounter the right conditions so 
that they don't collapse before they develop structure, and some of those 
last long enough that life gets started?

You're trying to inject the supernatural even though *every* single claim 
of supernatural agency ever made in the past has turned out to be not just 
wrong, but completely fucking ridiculous. The gods do not create fire, but 
people who were ignorant of chemistry insisted that must be the case. The 
gods do not make earthquakes, but people who were ignorant of geophysics 
insisted that must be the case. Lightning, thunder, volcanoes, life, 
tsunamis, hurricanes, plagues, disease - every single complex natural 
process/event ever attributed to the supernatural has turned out to have a 
completely ordinary natural cause.

Once we establish the truth about the origin of this universe has a 
perfectly natural origin, then the people making the gods of the gaps 
argument and the fine tuning argument will then switch to "well where does 
eternal inflation come from? *That* must be supernatural!"

It is childish to continue a 10,000+ year old streak of primitive ignorance 
and insist that *next* time the supernatural explanation will turn out to 
be right.
comments.author: ExperienceCounts2

required. What you mean is that it's impossible to prove non-existence.

Every positive logical statement can be expressed in negated form. If you 
couldn't prove a negative then you couldn't prove the negative form of a 
positive statement.

As the one who introduced the childish concept of gods into what is 
otherwise a rather simple expression of probability, it's up to *you* to 
present evidence or logic that the existence of gods would somehow alter a 
mathematical equation or a probability.

I could restart your claim that "a random (Easter Bunny free) universe is

You're claiming that the existence of a supernatural entity somehow affects 
probability. Any supernatural entity, ridiculous or revered, can be 
substituted without altering the claim.

You quote Richard Feynman when making your deistic argument? Either way, 
the problem with the fine tuning argument is that we don't know in how in

father had sex and made you the chances of you winning that race were 
extremely small. But if you weren't the one who won the race someone else 
would have. If your father had a good sperm count. Let's say 10^8 (100

comments.text:
“A philosopher once said, ‘It is necessary for the very existence of 
science that the same conditions always produce the same results.’ Well 
they don't! […] In fact, it is necessary for the very existence of science 
that minds exist which do not allow that nature must satisfy some 
preconceived conditions, like those of our philosopher […] Nature is not 
classical, dammit!” - Theoretical physicist Richard Feynman 

“The fine tunings, how fine tuned are they? Most of them are 1% sort of 
things. In other words, if a thing is off 1% different, everything gets 
bad. And the physicists could say, maybe those are just luck. On the other 
hand, this cosmological constant is tuned to one part in 10 to the 120, 120 
decimal places. Nobody thinks that’s accidental. That is not a reasonable 
idea.” - Theoretical physicist Leonard Susskind. So the cosmological 
constant needs to be set at one part in a trillion, trillion, trillion, 
trillion, trillion, trillion, trillion, trillion, trillion, trillion. 
Otherwise, the universe would be so drastically different that it would be 
impossible for us to evolve.

"The universe shows evidence of the operations of mind on three levels. The 
first level is the level of elementary physical processes in quantum 
mechanics. Matter in quantum mechanics is [...] constantly making choices 
between alternative possibilities according to probabilistic laws. [...] 
The second level at which we detect the operations of mind is the level of 
direct human experience. [...] It is reasonable to believe in the existence 
of a third level of mind, a mental component of the universe. If we believe 
in this mental component and call it God, then we can say that we are small 
pieces of God's mental apparatus.” - Theoretical physicist Freeman Dyson. 
Clearly Dyson isn’t arguing for the existence of the anthropomorphic god of 
the bible, but rather, something far more subtle and sophisticated, which 
is integrated within the functioning of the system both at the macro and 
micro levels. Cheers.
comments.author: Open-minded Skeptic
