comments.text:
+Liran Barsisa As I said before, I have absolute respect for anything that 
anyone personally believes. I don't give a fuck if they believe that pink 
faeries in drag created the universe.

When they abandon faith and start bullshitting me by claiming that their 
beliefs reflect the physical reality that pink faeries in drag created the 
universe, and when they start teaching children that is how the universe 
came to be, then they have crossed a very clear and obvious line that only 
superstitious people are unable to see: they're making statements of fact 
about physical reality that are clearly false and clearly extremely 
detrimental to the progress of the human species.

You make the false claim that science cannot answer everything, you present 
no evidence to support such a claim.

Religion has made that same false claims for thousands/millions of years 
and every single fucking time someone claims that something "must be caused 
by the gods" they have been proven wrong by science, yet *still* they claim 
the gods will eventually be found to be the cause of something.

Then you have the fucking gall to claim that old people are the ones 
fixated on their beliefs?

Religious people fixating on the belief that there are supernatural causes 
anywhere there is scientific uncertainty as to what natural process is at 
work is the clearest example of mind numbingly stupid fixation and willful 
ignorance that could possibly exist on this planet.

Tens of thousands, perhaps millions of years of abject failure, every 
single claim about the natural world made by any religion anywhere in the 
world for all of human history and you're *STILL* fixated on the idea that 
supernatural beings and supernatural processes will be responsible for 
something somewhere someday somehow for some reason?

After thousands of years of philosophizing about your gods by the most 
"brilliant" religious minds the human species can produce and you still 
can't even explain any of those? You still can't say where, when, how, or 
why these supernatural entities/processes will *finally* be found to be 
real?

No one has to tolerate or show any respect for the beliefs of the fat guy 
who keeps choosing to stand on the only hose that supplying air to a closed 
room. I don't give a flying fuck it he doesn't believe that air is 
necessary for the well being of the human species, I'll keep kicking his 
ass until he gets the fuck off the hose.

Likewise people who preach willful ignorance and superstition to children 
because they don't believe it's detrimental to the well being of the human 
species (in spite of endless concrete evidence to the contrary) had better 
get used to being intellectually kicked right square in the seat of their 
information source.

Teaching children that the supernatural world is real, and that you/your 
brand of religion/your brand of magic knows something about the structure 
and processes in the supernatural world is child abuse/child molesting.

Keep your faith, I don't give a shit about it. When you start claiming that 
your faith has evidence and that it represents physical reality then you 
give up your right to cry about your claims and evidence being challenged 
and your "logic" being derided when it's so obviously faulty that only the 
blinders of faith could make it seem otherwise.
comments.author: ExperienceCounts2

comments.text:
+ExperienceCounts2 Yes, you (as everyone else) should respect all people no 
matter what they believe, as beliefs are not actions and behavior. People 
decide what to do with their faith. 
In Hebrew there is a saying "Proper behavior precedes the Torah" - acting 
as a human being and respecting other is before anything else you learn.

One can find contradictions on any false claim and belief , and by doing so 
to disproof it. 
Science is divided to sections, and some of them are based on statistics 
and probability (and some are called "Empirical" so that people can examine 
them and call things true or false in 100% certainty, like math) . Such 
sections are actually beliefs too, and this includes History, Archeology 
and even what seems to be what you believe in (Evolution of everything in 
all scales, including of your ancestors). As such, not everything in 
science can be measured or have proofs to. One can't even measure the 
chances to some of what is decided to be true. All is left is believing in 
such things till someone finds otherwise.
On so many fields of science (even Physics), even when there are no 
evidences or solid proofs, theories arise and people start believing in 
them till proved otherwise. Theories come and go. Not all fields of science 
are accurate. All is bound to our senses, tools and understanding.
Generalizing all fields in science as 100% true or 100% observable is 
wrong. 
Also, just like in any field in science, if someone finds any hole in a 
theory that one believe in, he must ask himself if it's real or not, 
continue investigating current theory for possible explanations or ditch it 
for much better theories. In fact, the bigger the hole, the larger the 
chance the theory is false ( "Evolution of everything" has lots of holes 
and contradictions, for example, and needs stronger and stronger belief in 
order to still exist, but that's the only theory out there currently for 
origins of life as we know it).
Ruining something is usually much easier than building it.

If anyone know the "Matrix" movie, you can get interesting questions from 
it. I can't prove anything is real. I can't even prove the world existed a 
second ago - it could be that the universe just started in this state a 
second ago, with all of the people having a snapshot of memory from it. 
What I can say is that I believe it was existing before, because all 
evidences show it.
When someone is judged in court, no matter how much science is involved, no 
matter how many evidences there are, there is always the chance of being 
wrong in the verdict.

Science is the research of what exists in this universe, the searching of 
truth and knowledge. Science cannot answer everything. Science cannot 
answer why (and I'm not saying "how" or "when") the universe even exists 
and why it has laws that can be researched and aren't random (because the 
universe could run in any set of rules one can think of). Science can only 
answer to other questions, but not to those.
Why can there be physics and chemistry? I could think of any set of rules 
(even random ones) instead of all that is currently known.
Why is there even a universe? Why is there even an existence of anything?  
"Nothing" could easily be a nice alternative of a universe. In such a 
universe, there could be 0 atoms, 0 energy, 0 of everything that can be 
measured.
If there is a multiverse (infinite number of universes), why does it exist 
then? I could easily think of the non-existence of all multiverses...

If nothing "needs" to exist and nothing has a purpose, then life has no 
purpose too. End of life mean nothing as nothing goes after it to look for. 
There is no meaning to what anyone does in life since you will forget 
everything. This means everything is a lie, as Kohelet (king Solomon) said: 
becoming rich, having fun ,pleasure and memories, having a family, succeed 
in life in any way, everything you ever wished to have,... no a thing means 
anything anymore, since you die in the end and you get nothing after that. 
Even as you get older, you forget more and more things, as everything you 
had and experienced in life is gone and never to exist anymore.

In order to bypass the limitations of science, one need to have those 
questions and only then continue. 
In general, if you wish to find the truth beyond what can be measured or 
proved by tests, you cannot limit yourself to your senses (and you have 
already written it actually) and the empirical science.

I think that the older a person is, the more fixated he is in his believes. 
As I've written, I don't care what others believe in, as long as they do 
not offend others (and me) in any way. I can of course make conversations. 
I prefer not to make conversations with people who do not know how to 
respect others.

I'm very sorry if I ever offended anyone who read what I've written, but I 
don't think I deserve how you treated me. I was deeply offended though, and 
I hope you don't do it to any other stranger you meet outside, or people 
you care of.

I wish you best.
comments.author: Liran Barsisa

comments.text:
+kazumi sayuki Think further. We know how biological evolution works. Our 
sense evolved to detect things that make a difference to our survival, not 
to detect everything there is.

Our reason short-circuits the need for a lot of sensory inputs. We don't 
have to see in infrared in the dark forest because we can build sturdy 
shelter.

Evolution is slow and relatively unguided, and has the problem of 
hysteresis. Reason is quick and instantly adaptive, so it takes the place 
of the need for many senses.

So relying on sense over reason to determine "what is" is a mistake. Our 
senses do a piss-poor job of adapting to new input, while our reasoning can 
change instantaneously.

Time exists, all of it, past, present and future. Einstein's relativity 
means that what is the past for some observers is the future for others, 
and that relationship changes based on their relative motions. For 
perspectives to change like that, it must all exist.
comments.author: ExperienceCounts2

comments.text:

Mouse and The Green Giant are real and influence the natural world?

If not, then why on Earth would I need to treat claims that Lord Ganesha or 
Thor influence the natural world with respect?

The whole concept of gods and the supernatural are as intellectually 
bankrupt as it is possible to be.

I tend to save any respect that I have for ideas that respect reason and 
experience. Rational thought, evidence based reasoning, all that sort of 
stuff.

I could give a flying fuck who is reading what I say. What I care about is 
whether I'm on the side of reason and evidence. Anyone claiming that 
supernatural forces are real/at work in the natural world, or worse, that 
they know why those supernatural forces are at work, is full of shit and 
shall remain so (in my book) until they present evidence to support their 
claims.

Every claim of fact ever attributed to any gods or any religion has turned 
out to be false when rationally examined. Anyone who expects a different 
results when it comes to supernatural claims about the origins of, or 
events within our universe is an idiot.

Present testable evidence or incontrovertible logic to the contrary and 
I'll make a full apology and take back every "fuck", "shitbag" and "addle 
brained religious lunatic" comment I've ever posted since I first started 
online in 1985.

+Candra Adi Putra Standard religious fallacy. Pascal's Wager was shot down, 
ages ago. Look it up sometime.

Your gods are not the only gods. There are at least 3,000 named gods, 
probably many times that have been invented over human history. What are 
the odds that you've randomly chosen the right one? You've likely never 
even read about the other gods, you almost certainly don't even know their 
names.

You chose your gods, there's at least a 1 in 3,000 chance you've picked the 
wrong gods and then *you're* the one that's likely to be in trouble for 
choosing the wrong side.

Atheists don't believe in or worship any gods, so if there is a god and 
it's a benevolent one, we're fine. If the gods are jealous ones, all the 
people who worship other gods will be the ones eating poop for an eternity.

You might as well tell an atheist that the Easter Bunny will judge them, 
since the evidence for an Easter Bunny is the same as for any gods: there's 
a book, some people say the characters in the book are real. That's it.

comments.text:
You've missed the definition of god. God is an entity , not a creature. 
God isn't a physical thing as it's not an entity that was created in the 
universe, it created the universe.
When you ask what made X, you mean that something was superior (or before) 
to X in order to make it, so X cannot be god since something else has 
created it.
If god was in the same level as the rules you are living in , it means it's 
bound to them. Since he made the rules, it doesn't mean it is bound to them.
If I make a game, with a specific set rules, does it make me a part of the 
game, and do I have to follow the rules even before the game was started?

The idea of putting god into a physical set of rules isn't a new one. It's 
actually started from the logic of creating gods, by making sculptures. 
When people worship something they've just created, this is a paradox as 
what they've created couldn't have created them...

Another example of an eternal entity is an idea. More specifically, Math. 
Math is full of ideas and rules that aren't bound to any rule in the 
universe. They were always there and will always exists, even if there is 
no universe. Math is absolute and contains only one single truth. Any 
"paradox" you see in math, you'd probably believe someone is messing with 
you.

Also, you speak of time, but it seems that time had a beginning and nothing 
else was before, so this is the reality as we know it.
And even though this video suggests there could be something before the 
"big bang" , most scientists (including the most known one -  Stephen 
Hawking) believe it isn't so, and that time and the entire universe really 
had a beginning.

In any case, I think one of the arguments of how come god exists, is that 
reality has rules, and quite strict ones. I could easily think of an 
alternative universe where there are no rules where gravity changes 
randomly every 1 hour, or nothing is actually existing. Why do we have a 
universe at all? Why do we have rules in it?
The reason we have science is that there are rules in our universe, and 
there are people willing to discover them and help mankind.
I think science is here to answer the questions of how, and not why. 

Even though I'm not a christian (because god having a son that cancels its 
own laws even though one of them is that all are sealed and cannot be 
changed is just against my logic) , I like the debates of creationalists vs 
evolution. more specifically this rather old one:
watch?v=UKyyaURZW-o
They show there some interesting ideas of both sides. 

No matter what you choose to believe in, I think its the actions you make 
that truly matter and is the right religion in my belief. 
When you do choose to believe in something, I think it's best to check it 
from all directions, and if there is a single contradiction (especially 
within itself), it means it's flawed and must be explained, otherwise it's 
incorrect to believe in.

comments.text:
+An Octorok "so no one can really say for sure there isn't some supreme 
being out there controlling everything" - since every behavior in the 
universe is easily predicted by interactions with the entire system, 
without an observable influence (i.e. something that looks like a 
stochastic process). Everything we see today in the macro-universe is 
deterministic. On the quantum level it's perfectly stochastic.

An intelligent controller would generate certain patterns that aren't 
always followed. Intelligence comes up with outcomes that are neither 
random, nor determined by simple interactions that are almost perfectly 
predictable (limited by our level of knowledge and technology).

In other words, there is no evidence of someone controlling the universe, 
as in, there is evidence that nobody is controlling it.

Now, the original claim - religion, is false in this sense, because it 
never provided any evidence. So this is a figment of the imagination. We 
can come up with all kinds of crazy shit. That doesn't mean we should 
actually endorse the possibility.

We won't know when we die, because by definition, death is the moment that 
the brain ceases to function at the most basic level. So knowing, a much 
more complex process, is impossible after death.
comments.author: Donnie

comments.text:
+Burhan the Somali that what exists? The word? The word "God" exists. 
However any definition of it refers to something that doesn't exist, since 
it describes something that is either logically impossible, or something 
that can't be observed.

Let me give you an example:
Stars may exist outside the observable universe, because it wouldn't break 
any rules, and we see stars everywhere, and we define what they are very 
well, because we observe them.
A teapot cannot exist in the orbit of Alpha Centauri, because it needs to 
be more concrete. Who made the teapot, where is the teapot exactly, what 
shape is it, what color, what size, what material? That's the definition of 
the object we refer to. Any given definition is near impossible. It's so 
improbable that absolutely nobody who is clinically mentally sane would 
actually consider it true.
A theoretical particle can exist, even if not observed, if you describe it, 
and the description is logically sound and correct.

Now, since we can't prove that even we exist, or that Zeus doesn't stand on 
Mount Olympus throwing lightning, let's just be practical and admit: God 
(and any other related supernatural entity) does not exist, the same way 
Zeus doesn't exist, nor that teapot in orbit of Alpha Centauri.

When we do discover a white, clay teapot with 6 strawberries painted on it, 
in orbit of Alpha Centauri, in equatorial orbit, with a periapsis equal to 
the apoapsis, at a distance of 4.3241 light minutes, with a mass of 0.42kg 
and a total internal volume of 0.98 dm3, in tidal lock with the star, then 
we could admit the possibility that there might be, in fact, a god.

comments.text:
+ExperienceCounts2 It's about time you brought out the core of your beliefs 
so that we can observe the fallacies in it.  The fallacy in your beliefs 
has to do with philosophy, not science.

First off, you claim that every single supernatural explanation turned out 
to be false in all of history, this is a small part of the fallacy in your 
argument, because only many of the supernatural occurrences have proven to 
be false.  There are still some that are unaccounted for that (maybe) we'll 
find evidence to disprove, but until then we cannot dismiss it, as 
generally their evidence for it is the fact that it cannot be explained.

Next, I'll try to use more descriptive words so you understand the fallacy 
in your "easter bunny" argument.  The easter bunny is proved false because 
the conditions required for that case are false (the entire easter bunny is 
a tradition that would discontinue with tradition, however in the case of a 
god, the god would live regardless of people's belief in it, continuing to 
exist in it's initial conditions, unless the initial conditions were proved 
false)  Also keep in mind that religious texts are not scientific papers; 
they will not go into detail about the scientific process of how their god 
created the universe or any other act, but only that they did it.  And as 
far as I have seen, initial conditions for a god do not include people 
experiencing the supernatural.

And now for a core fallacy: the assumption that because most cases have 
been proven false, that all cases must then be false.  In statistics, this 
is called extrapolation, and has the potential to (meaning to or not) 
misrepresent data.  This is also true with things that are well developed, 
such as the laws of physics, or any science for that matter; for example, 
we have not observed gravity act upon EVERY object according to the way we 
describe through laws, therefore our scientific laws cannot be proven 
absolutely correct: even though we have absolutely no evidence of a 
macro-object that does not obey the laws of physics does not mean it does 
not exist--and the same can be said about a deity. Science also isn't as 
exact as we would like it to be, we learn new things about everything the 
more we look into it (some examples are the change in structure in atoms, 
the beginning of the universe (or lack thereof), the center of the 
universe, evolution, or electricity, where we still have a lot to learn. 
 Your argument also assumes that everything we know today is correct, and 
this is false (and that is shown through advances in technology and changes 
in theories, as well as some things that are observed that contradict or 
cannot be explained by our current understanding.  This is also very key to 
proving whether or not a deity can exist, if we only had the information we 
have today, we would never prove it one way or the other).

I hope this has cleared things up for you.  I'm sure there are some things 
I've missed as well, but they can be addressed later if needed.

P.S.
Just because it can't be proven that a deity cannot exist doesn't mean 
there has to be one (which is another fallacy), it just means that a deity 
existing does not contradict with science or logic.  Along with that, that 
doesn't mean that every religious quack is correct just because of the 
possibility of a deity.
comments.author: qw3rty01

comments.text:
+MLP Fede Maybe you can answer a question that he refuses to: Can we not 
discard the Easter Bunny theory of the origin of the cosmos because it's 
illogical?

The point is that once you accept that supernatural explanations might turn 
out to be real, then you must answer the next logical question: which 
supernatural explanations are real?

Since there is no definition of/structure/logic to the supernatural world 
then you cannot possibly distinguish between "more supernatural" and "less 
supernatural" or "correct supernatural" and "incorrect supernatural" or 
"slightly bluish green supernatural" and "orangey-pink supernatural". If 
you accept that one supernatural cause might be real, you have to accept 
that *any* supernatural cause might be real.

To me that's the core idiocy of supernatural beliefs. It's beyond 
intellectually lazy, it's the intellectually comatose going on vacation to 
relax, laying on the floor and washing down a fistful of tranquilizers with 
bottle of tequila.

The defense of supernatural claims is just human vanity/arrogance parading 
around as "oh my definition of supernatural is so much better than those 
other definitions of supernatural that mine could be real while all those 
others are just silly". It's just religion in an alternate uniform "oh, all 
those other gods are just silly but *my* gods are *real*"

The Easter Bunny theory of the origin of the cosmos is equivalent to any 
other supernatural theory about the origin of the cosmos, which includes 
all creation myths from all religions, and every batshit crazy claim ever 
made by inmates in  insane asylums.

The other point is that every supernatural explanation ever made has turned 
out to be false. All of them. Not a single one turned out to be true, in 
all of human history. So it's perfectly reasonable to ask how many 
thousands/millions of supernatural explanations have to fail before it can 
be considered "safe" to dismiss all supernatural explanations out of hand?

If we witness a billion supernatural explanations for something all 
failing, do rational adults still have to hold the door open for the 
supernatural claims, just in case the 1,000,000,001st one is right? Ten 
billion? A trillion? Where do we draw the line?

The trillionth time, when we entertain the Gargantuan Four Dimensional 
Chameleon theory of the universe wherein a ten trillion light year long 
chameleon (whose sacred name is Englebert) found it neccessary to take on 
the exact size, shape and color of our universe in order to camouflage 
himself from the Evil Wizard known as Tim... if that explanation turns out 
to be false too, do we *really* have to keep an "open mind" that the ones 
about the magic gods of Iron age nomads conjuring the universe from 
nothing, or the indifferent, coalition of unnamed deities who simply group 
farted the universe into existence and walked away?

The people who call for rational people to "keep an open mind" are 
invariably the ones who are completely unable to answer the next logical 
question "about what?" The reply from the superstitious is invariably some 
variant of "well... for anything really".

I say fuck it, "anything" has worn out its welcome as causation for 
everything we're uncertain about. It can go get stuffed, and anyone who 
seriously proposes "anything" as a possible origin of the universe is a 
moron, first class, with honors, and probably also wears a diaper.

As Feynman said, maybe we never get to the center of the onion, maybe it's 
just more and more layers no matter how far down we dig. I think that the 
only rational thing is to say "we don't yet know what this natural process 
is" Seriously proposing that "maybe *THIS* time it's magic!" is as 
irrational and idiotic as proposing "maybe *THIS* time I'll throw myself at 
the floor and fall up to the ceiling because gravity won't see me"

comments.text:
+Donnie Yes, I've rejected the other theories through the scientific method.

As we're not really going to get anywhere without me actually going to 
explain my theory's inner workings.

My hypothesis is a eternal, closed system "educated guess" on how the 
universe recycles its self.

I base my hypothesis on the big bang, as it spurs from it, so lets start 
there.

The big bang theory starts off with the universe and space expanding from a 
single point, but I disagree on it on the basis that the universe is 
infinite and thus, it's a closed system no matter what you do it and thus, 
space does not change.

Since we do not really have anything which is anything like the "big bang", 
so I had to go with its smaller version, the black hole.

The black hole is basically a collapsed star, a star which has collapsed 
into a single point where nothing can escape from it.

And this is where the big bang fails at the first hurdle, the big bang 
cannot spontaneously explode, no matter how much space has been warped by 
it (so the claim that space was so warped that it had to explode is not 
true).

But then I say that the system constantly recycles its materials, so I 
looked up "Hawking radiation" (not going to explain it in detail here), but 
apparently, black holes loose mass as they evaporate gradually through time 
(this has been proved through the use of the hydron collider as black holes 
have been created and have evaporated before they have a chance to eat 
anything up).

So, what generally happens, is a black hole gradually releases mass, until 
it can't remain stable anymore and explode, releasing the rest of its mass.

As it looses its mass, the gravitational effect that is created by the 
sheer mass of the black hole gradually gets weaker and weaker, thus the 
galaxies begin to separate due to the loss of the gravitational field, 
thereby explaining how all of the galaxies are all red shifted and appear 
to be expanding at an accelerating rate.

But that's not exactly true, all galaxies are all travelling at different 
speeds, so some are blue shifted, others are red shifted, so in reality, 
it's hard to really decide from the Hubble pictures.

Also keep in mind that we are travelling in the galaxy too, so the fact we 
are moving too will effect the other galaxies shifts too.

The theory mainly relies on the Hawking radiation theory, which I don't 
really find all that convincing since it relies on particles popping out 
from nowhere and colliding shortly afterwards, but I find it a better story 
then the big bang theory.

If you find any problems in this, it would be nice for you to dispute it 
with me.
comments.author: Ben 1337

then forming my own hypothesis from that data.

But through research on how the universe reacts with mass and thermal 
activity, that I have really stopped believing in the big bang theory 
altogether (and all of the subsequent ending variations) and formulated my 
own theory about how the universe works based on that research.

I also don't feel ready to believe that a god that only appeared 
approximately 2000 years ago created everything we see and feel, simply 
because every religion kinda says the same thing.

I agree that exceptional claims need exceptional evidence to support them.

People really do really need to be critical about the data that's been 
presented to them and not believe what they're fed.

comments.text:
+Alec Bethune When people shut down others with opposing beliefs, I get the 
feeling it's because their very existence is dependent on those beliefs. Or 
at least they think it is. Both religious and atheist alike. Both have 
developed strong beliefs about how and why they exist, how all of existence 
started and how it will end, and for what purpose. They must fiercely 
insist on the certainty of their beliefs, because if they're wrong, it may 
negate the meaning of their own existence. And the fear that without that 
meaning, they may cease existing at all, at least after physical death. 
This fear causes some to desperately try to convince others. If they do, 
their belief is confirmed. But if they don't, there's the terror that they 
might be wrong. People seem to be more stubborn on this topic than any 
other, maybe they can't help it or can't see it. It may be a survival 
instinct in response to the imminent threat of death, of non existence. 
Animals, on the other hand, don't seem to have the capacity for self 
reflection enough to know that they will die someday, so they 
don't perceive the threat of future death. Only immediate threats of death 
trigger their survival instincts.

+An Octorok "Religion is history and moral codes" - as a historical 
document, it is one of the worst and most unreliable. It's hard to 
determine whether anything from the gospels actually happened, and by 
looking at their content, the conclusion is that we shouldn't trust it. It 
can be used as some sort of insight, like the way you would look at the 
tantrums thrown by a mentally insane person when you're trying to determine 
what that person witnessed.

As a source of morals, it is the worst possible place. Everywhere, where 
people are ruled by religion, the moral values are on the ground. And why 
shouldn't they be? The bible for example tells people to kill, rape, have 
sex with own daughters, kill again, kill children, burn people, etc.

"Thus it and science can coexist. " - only if there is a very thick wall of 
ignorance between them. A realm of "I'm not touching this subject", a mode 
where you can disconnect your brain when it comes to religion. My wife has 
been like this. A devout fanatical christian, yet she loves science. Every 
time I told her that something about her religion was contradicting 
science, she didn't want to listen, she got angry. But she loved talking 
about science. Until it got to religion. I wasn't trying to flush religion 
out of her. I even went with her to church when she wanted to. But in the 
end, with all the science I inundated her with, she began to really doubt 
whether christianity has any credibility. Only after she really understood 
what evolution by natural selection is (she didn't know exactly), only 
after she understood the classical laws of motion, and saw simulations made 
by me and not only me, did she understand that most of what she learned 
from religion was in contradiction with science.
Then she picked up the bible. She was told by the priest that she can't 
just read it. That the reading must be preceded by long sessions of 
prayers, talking with priests, so they would tell you how to interpret it. 
But she didn't do any of that. She knew that she wanted to see what's 
actually there, not what priests want her to see. So she took it, read the 
first page, and shut it closed in horror, then burst out laughing. It was 
the stupidest thing she has ever read. She then continued to read, 
annotating it. That book was full with sticky notes on every page, with 
annotations from her.
But she didn't go past Genesis. It was beyond stupid and horrible. Stupid 
as in - written by a retard. Horrible as in - that retard was also a 
merciless savage mass murderer and rapist - a sociopath, a maniac. As a 
impressionable woman, she once even had a nightmare once after reading the 
more explicit depictions of mass murder.

And she thought that other religions can't be that bad. I showed her parts 
of the Qur'an. Chilling. Then she read greek mythology. They're all the 
same.

Whoever worships these texts today either never read them, or are too sick 
to be treated as humans any more.

+Donnie not at all. Because the who created a creator idea assumes time and 
we believe time is actually something man thinks is linear and that God is 
outside of man made time and space. The human mind, even using math and 
observation, cannot think beyond a certain dimension. It is just not 
possible. So people dismiss it because they think of God as an entity that 
exists, and existence to us has space and time but we find it hard to think 
outside of that frame of reference. And even if the how of science explains 
the laws we observe that create movement of inanimate forms and life of 
animate forms, we are still not able to perceive beyond what we can observe 
or hypothesize, and our thinking is still limited by both our experience as 
humans before becoming a scientist and by just being human in 
general. There are things that we will not know for a long time to come, 
and there are things that seem certain now that will be found in error at 
some point. But we will still be limited by our human mind. The Bible 
clearly states that God is spirit, outside of time and space. We look at 
God as the why and the reason and we may naturally anthropomorphize Him but 
that is normal behavior for humans. However, what convinces me is the 
things that occur in the spirit as it were whereas I will do or say or 
think or pray or want something specific and there is a response. Now this 
happens not only more frequently as I do these things, but has become quite 
targeted and precise. Being as it was only in my spirit or consciousness 
and that I made no physical effort to do anything or tell anyone, and yet 
the responses occurred anyways, how would one explain that? Certainly 
randomness and chance are out the window because these things happen in 
response and depending on my choice of frequency. They are turning thoughts 
we cannot measure into something concrete that we can, or in some cases 
knowledge beforehand that  later turns out to be measurable and observable 
but nonetheless does occur just as explained earlier. So we could say 
somehow my thoughts send out signals which we cannot see to other forces we 
cannot see and they react in such a way as to send something back that 
gives me the thing I want. But then you have to ask why? Is it good for a 
life form to get what he wants that is good for him so as to propagate the 
species and keep the life form alive longer? But if that is what is 
important, why is that important? Why does it matter to the spirit or 
cosmos or whatever it s receiving and responding whether the life form 
lives longer and multiplies, or not? If the forces are inanimate chemical 
reactions or some other form of wave or particle or what have you, why do 
they "care" to respond to my whims and wants? Perhaps they respond to 
everything, but if I want something bad it usually does not happen so it 
seemingly does respond only to good things, which is what the Bible says 
about getting the desires of our heart if it is good for us and is in 
alignment with His will. Science, if that is what you attribute response to 
prayer to be, would seem to give credence to this idea. But why then? If it 
responds to anything and not just us and our whims, why only respond to the 
good things that help us as a species survive longer and attain more 
happiness, not at anyone else's expense. Why does it matter to an inanimate 
particle and why would it not respond to our wants if those wants come from 
a bad place and would cause harm? How can those particles or waves or what 
we call the spirit differentiate between the two, and again, why would it 
do that? How could it do that with no standard of right and wrong or 
goodness or even intelligence? I am assuming you take me at my word when I 
make the statements about the back and forth of specific, targeted prayer 
and other things that we as humans do and how they coincide with what the 
Bible says. I know I am being honest though you have no way to know that as 
you do not know me. However, I have written down many specific examples of 
such answered prayers and wants and knowing things before they happen or 
being given information even from afar that eases my mind or lets me know 
something, and as I told no one and as I put no physical effort into 
gathering the information, and as I have seen these things happen only when 
I choose to ask for them, and as they are so targeted and precise, timed 
and influenced by the frequency of my requests, and as they only occur if 
they are for the good as we perceive it, and as I cannot find any 
correlation to randomness or chance that makes any sense, what then would 
you attribute that to if not what we call the love of God, the why to 
science's how? And if someone cannot consider that option, perhaps that 
close-mindedness is just further proof of the limits we either innately 
have as humans or which we place upon ourselves which leave us wholly 
unable to understand what we would call God or what non-believers would 
call the theory of everything.

I always have a question in my math class but I've never ask anybody about 
it.  In math class they always use a bouncing ball as an example to 
calculate rebound of the ball.  eg. 1/2 of its height when it rebound.  
Then technically it will be an infinite time of bouncing after you drop the 
ball on the ground or so to say, everything is bouncing.  But what we know 
or what I know the world is not like that.  If you drop a ball on the 
ground even if the ball rebound 1/2 of its height, without a brute force to 
press the ball onto the ground the ball do stop bouncing.  If you input the 
equation into a computer to simulate.  The computer does simulate the ball 
will keep bouncing infinitely.  So Is there something wrong in the math and 
physics? Or there has another physics to describe this phenomenon.

If we use this concept to back track the beginning of the universe.  Could 
it not be not what we expect?  Like the ball doesn't keep rebound 
infinitely? The universe doesn't shrink infinitely small?  Maybe it does 
comes in a singularity like the ball will stick to the ground after its 
being drop and 1/2 of its height every rebound?  Can't figure it out here,

Answering this requires a little bit of quantum knowledge but only the 
basic concept which is: there exists a minimum of energy.
Essentially a quantized minimum packet of energy. As the ball moves, and

comments.author: HapZungLam

comments.text:
I can explain it, but a lot of people in my physics class wouldn't 
understand it.

Well, assuming we are in a frictionless area. The ball produces no 
friction, the ground has no friction, and there is no air resistance. Due 
to the elastic qualities of the ball, it will bounce when it hits another 
surface. When it hits the surface and bounces, there is an impulse. Because 
the ball bounces, the impulse is very large. Of course when the ball hits, 
there will be a loss of energy. It will lose energy in a variety of things 
such as heat energy. Most importantly though is that momentum has to be 
conserved. When the ball hits, its momentum due to speed converts into the 
earth as momentum due to mass. After this transfer of momentum, the ball 
losses half of its overall momentum on the rebound.

sorry for the word salad. I tried my best but my thoughts are jumbled today.

something abstract, like a population explosion.

than light relative to something else if the space between them expands.

+TheByQQ Maybe I can help explain this with a little math (skip the parts 
that you don't need an answer to I tried to answer as much as possible). 
There are different kinds of infinity for example.
(3 + infinity) and (infinity). If you add 3 to infinity the sum is not 
going to be any bigger obviously but it's bigger than plane infinity. What 
Everett was getting at is the volume of an infinite glass that is half full 
means the volume of water is also infinite because as the cup grows larger 
in volume the water matches it to keep it half full.

If you pour a finite amout of water into this cup then you won't change 
anything. If you pour an infinite amount of water into the cup you will 
still never fill it up. This is because we started with it half full.

The cup still has a halfway point. Just because it's volume is infinite 
doesn't mean we cannot measure it in one way or another. We know the cup is 
half full so we know the height of the cup is twice as big as the height of 
the water roughly. We can even write an equation for it. H (height of the 
cup) = 2 * (A+infinite)
A is the initinial amout of water it takes to make the cup half full. 
The halfway point isn't a number but we could come up with an answer 
because of how it's defined and it's relations with other things. 

Both are infinite but not the same kind of infinite. Infinite means 
increasing forever. When you add or multiply with infinity you get a 
different kind of infinity.

Everett's hotel paradox is not the kind of paradox that ends up with a 
false conclusion. All it means is when we deal with infinity we get very 
impractical results to deal with it. We've been dealing with regular 
infinity as in...
1 2 3... and so on, there's also this kind of infinite
0.01           0.001         0.0001... and so on. The list of numbers 
between 0 and 1 is also infinite and an even bigger headache is what his 
paradox says. Any questions?

comments.text:
2 is not about scale invariance, but just how smooth all the quantities you 
want to consider are. 

For example: The absolute value function |x| can be differentiated once 
before it becomes discontinuous (step function).

Physicists usually stick to smooth (infinitely differentiable) functions; 
or sometimes analytic functions because it is easy to handle them. But 
mathematicians being more resourceful and clever know that that is not 
necessary and we can get by with less. Usually for most equations for 
fundamental physics we only need two derivatives (think wave equation) and 
so all the stuff like gravity, electromagnetism only needs to be twice 
differentiable.

comments.text:
Good video but a lot of errors.

1. Around 13.7 billion years ago, the spatial distance between everything 
was 0. This is the time of the Big Bang.

2. His arguments seem to suggest that either infinite space or infinite 
differentiability of the metric is needed for this to work. Neither 
statement is true.

General Relativity requires twice differentiability, but one can write down 
an expanding Universe without any such restrictions.

3. "Singularity" is in fact the least misleading term in the name. In 
mathematics if something becomes infinite somewhere/when then the thing is 
called "singular". e.g. f(x) = 1/x is singular at x = 0.

It has nothing to do with "happened at a single point". e.g. f(x,y,z) = 1/z 
 is singular along an entire plane. 

They could have just checked 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_singularity

4. Singularity does not mean "we don't know". It does indicate a breaking 
down of General Relativity, but that is because we known quantum mechanics 
is important there. Whether this gets rid of the singularity or not is an 
open question.

5. "Time does not make sense" is a correct conclusion but that is not 
because "our models breakdown" just like at the North pole North makes no 
sense, but there is nothing breaking down there! In fact if our theories 
are wrong then "time will not breakdown".

6. "Seemingly arbitrary laws of physics" is very very misleading. There are 
very very good reasons for why the laws of physics are exactly what they 
are. These are more of a technical nature but these reasons do exist.

7. The Universe having a collapsing phase "before" the Big Bang is very 
very problematic because of the second law of thermodynamics "entropy 
always increases". So normal everyday physics pretty much rules out a prior 
collapsing phase. It does show up in other theories but their interaction 
with the second law is not very well understood.

Basically the argument is a follows.

a. The entropy should increase with time.
b. This means the early Universe had very low entropy.
c. Gravity causes collapse of things. So if something is uniform intially 
it will clump up. This is what happened in our Universe. Early universe was 
mostly uniform, but now we have galaxies and stars.
d. This must be true in the earlier collapsing phase. So a collapsing phase 
cannot give rise to a very uniform Universe "after the Big Bang".
comments.author: Kartik Prabhu

furthered high levels of medical, technological and scientific advances. It 
is one of the best questions God have given us to ask. BUT, this line of 
“Questioning” is also intellectually and scientifically cyclical that has 
to have an end, or the question can’t be asked. Saying everything had to 
have a “cause”, but this cause goes on eternally backwards is illogical, 
because that in itself is an “eternal cause” and ends up making (A) the 
creator of (A) or Eternal is Eternal and that is a logical absurdity. 
 Eternal means = “has
always been”. Eternal means it has no beginning and has no end. For the 
Atheist to insist on asking if God had a beginning is as logical as the 
Atheist asking if “Matter and space” had a beginning. They do have their 
deity, It is their God of the gap, they worship “Eternal”, a belief that 
can’t be explained, observed or tested. Yet they bow down to it, they 
promote it, call on it, bend it, and use it when they reach the end of the 
beginning that has no beginning. They will even philosophically use it as 
beyond our comprehension - the deity of omniscience.     

It will boil down to a pretty simple answer and a very logical and more 
probable one at that. If there is a God, and he is the “Creator”, then He 
is greater than the sum of his creation, and would not be subject to what 
we see as creation, i.e. the cause and effect of matter. God is eternal, 
not matter. Therefore, you either see "Matter" as Eternal, or you see God 
as eternal, but both are not true eternal. You either have mindless matter 
as eternal, giving way to Constants/laws/intelligence/morals/determinism, 
or you have a mindful Creator that gave way to 
order/constants/laws/intelligence/morals/free will… to even deny Him.

comments.text:
I'll explain the way Einstein explained it to us scientists. He said that 
space itself is not an empty void but rather a fabric that can twist, bend, 
stretch and compress. Now you can think of planets, galaxies etc like 
buttons on an elastic fabric. When the fabric stretches the distance 
between the buttons increase. So when space itself expands, so to does the 
distance between objects in it. But unlike buttons which are fixed to one 
point, celestial objects can move around due to gravitational attraction, 
this results in objects orbiting each other. So celestial objects move both 
by the expansion of space and gravitational attraction.

As for the other part, dark matter is not what is causing the universe to 
expand. Dark matter is what holds galaxies together, without it galaxies 
would not exist because they simply do not have enough mass on their own. 
What scientists believe is causing the universe to expand is dark energy. 
This energy has never been detected so we cannot say exactly what it is but 
we believe it makes up around 70% of the total energy in the universe. It 
is also believed that dark energy could be another fundamental force of 
nature. We already know of 4 but dark energy could be a 5th. Only time will 
tell.
comments.author: Marsilio V.M.

The problem with "everywhere stretch" theory is there is less evidence (if 
any) than the "big bang" theory.  All parts of the universe are expanding 
away from each other and the further out the faster it is expanding (except 
for the Andromeda galaxy which is going to collide with the Milky Way - 
since we are in the local group).  We know this from the red and blue 
signatures of the Doppler effect.

MinutePhysics seems to claim this as scientific fact to disprove the big 
bang, but I don't see the point.  Is he promoting string theory, but using 
"everywhere stretch" as the label?  Even that string theory can be "proved" 
seven different ways mathematically (from seven different perspectives), 
there isn't any physical evidence that we can study empirically.

So it's really neat how you like the "everywhere stretch" as an idea, but 
it doesn't hold with the big bang theory.﻿

I don't get why people tend to see science and religion on opposite sides. 
What if god really is just the sum of all rules - the logic behind 
everything. The bible does not really define what or who god is.
The bible (and so do other religious books) states a lot of what people 
interpreted and thought at the time it was written. They didn't have the 
math and knowledge so they came up with ways to explain rain, the stars 
etc. with their interpretation of a "human-like" godly beeing. What they 
were really trying to capture was the essence of it all, but they wrote it 
down in their own, 2000+years old words.
If we read it today, we should take care to "translate" this into our 
modern world. When we refer to rain today, we don't refer to a "man in the

comments.text:
+Connor Battilana
I guess I'm worried about becoming complacent. With a question such as 
this, there is a sense of giving up on very important matters. I was more 
or less pointing to my/our ignorance in the end by acknowledging the 
problem of infinite explanation, though I still find the one I favour a 
hard idea to shake. It *does* have an important benefit over the other, 
namely that the universe is purposed in some sense and didn't somehow 
spontaneously be; I think I have much less a problem with one (or few) 
necessary property(ies), than a whole host of contingent things bouncing 
around on ad infinitum through a circle/chain of universes with no unitary 
force binding them together. At this stage, yeah I guess I don't know, and 
maybe I don't want to admit it. I hope to somehow find out one day.

*Aside:* I like to think that logic can help in dispelling flippantly 
spoken characteristics of God, and therefore get closer to working out what 
it could be, which means we could find out if such a thing is likely to 
exist. That seems like evidence to me, but is not empirical. E.g. gender 
and causal intervention seem to imply spatiotemporal properties, which 
doesn't seem consistent with the idea of God being Creator (essential 
assumption). This to me points to God being some kind of conscious force if 
it exists, and that it won't break physics laws in virtue of standing 
outside time.
comments.author: TheShamansQuestion

comments.text:
+Donnie You are right, but I disagree that god is supernatural. He might be 
supernatural to our everyday-life experiences, just as the maxwell eqn. or 
the speed of light is supernatural to our experience. Still we know its 
there. Don't take this example too serious, because comparing god to 
scientific equations is a rather bad comparison, but I think you get the 
idea.

My thought is more like this: You can imagine a completely different set of 
rules to describe a universe, equations that are consistent and logical in 
themselfes. They would (if they were real) define a completely different 
universe. However, we find the universe to work in a very specific way. 
Don't you wonder why it is exactly that way and not any of the other 
possibilities? That's the kind of "logic behind everything" that I mean. 
It's not outside of nature, its the very core of it and its something 
undiscoverable - by definition.

comments.text:
All those words *do* having meanings. It's when they're used because 
they're popular and not because they fit the idea being expressed that 
problems arise.
When I was a grad student in English in the 80s, I was told by a professor 
that no matter your subject or your scholarship, you couldn't get your 
paper read at a conference unless you'd figured out some way to include the 
word 'deconstruction' in the abstract.
Years later I was at the National Association of Broadcasters convention in 
Las Vegas, the year the buzzword was 'plasma.'
I was at a sushi restaurant with fellow attendees, when a large group of 
Japanese businessmen sat down at a long table.
"Watch this," I said to my friends and loudly intoned the word:
"PLASMA."
All of the men stopped talking. They looked over at our booth and smiled 
and nodded at me. A couple even rose and bowed.
I had known the magic word. I was imbued with meaning, surrounded by a 
nimbus of signification.
comments.author: Joseph Clay Thompson

comments.text:
+thethirdthefourth Disclaimer I actually do respect your view, so forgive 
me if I come across as rude.
"we ultimately have no meaning"
To be fair, if you're going to live forever anyway, then your time on Earth 
has no meaning. Having a finite life makes your time more valuable. As for 
having a greater purpose, I never understood why that's so important to 
people. You can set your own goals, you know...
"morality, legacy, pleasure, science"
Morality is most likely part biology part social norms, so that's not going 
anywhere. Most people don't want to rape and murder regardless of whether 
they think they'll go to hell.
Legacy, well you can "live on" through your works, but that too is finite. 
But why do you need to last forever? See first point of why mortality makes 
your existence more valuable. The fact that you are here NOW is what 
matters.
Pleasure is also biological and psychological so I don't see why you would 
need a deity for that to exist...
Science has no relation to religion whatsoever so that seems a bit 
irrelevant.
"No God, no intrinsic worth, no morals, no meaning, just death."
No god, no. But you most likely don't have Zeus or Vishnu in your life 
either and you've gotten along, no?
No intrinsic worth, no. But why do we need to have intrinsic worth? Is it 
not enough to be worthy to our loved ones and our fellow man, and most 
importantly, ourselves?
Morals I already addressed. If religion=morality, then all criminals would 
be atheists and vice versa. If you mean that morals have no value, I see 
how that could be sad, but many human constructs have no objective value, 
yet are valued by us immensely. Such as pets, rainbows, video games, etc.
"Is that how we want to view reality?"
I don't think we have a choice what we believe. You can deceive yourself, 
but deep down you believe what you believe.
And personally I would rather believe the truth than just what is pleasant 
because that's the only thing I can work with.

As 2005, Philip Skell, a retired chemistry professor at Pennsylvania State 
University and former member of the National Academy of Sciences, wrote the 
following [Skell2005]:
Scientific journals now document many scientific problems and criticisms of 
evolutionary theory. ... Many of the scientific criticisms of which I speak 
are well known by scientists in various disciplines, including the 
disciplines of chemistry and biochemistry, in which I have done my work. 
... None of the great discoveries in biology and medicine over the past 
century depended on guidance from Darwinian evolution -- it provided no 
support. ... In my judgment, this state of affairs has persisted mainly 
because too many scientists were afraid to challenge what had become a 
philosophical orthodoxy among their colleagues. Fortunately, that is 
changing as many scientists are now beginning to examine the evidence for 
neo-Darwinism more openly and critically in scientific journals.
In 2001 the Discovery Institute, the principal sponsoring organization for 
the intelligent design movement, began to form a list of scientists who 
question evolution. Each of the scientists on this list, known as "A 
Scientific Dissent from Darwinism," affirmed the following statement 
[Dissent2010]:

We are skeptical of claims for the ability of random mutation and natural 
selection to account for the complexity of life. Careful examination of the 
evidence for Darwinian theory should be encouraged.
As of April 2012, this list had 840 names.

top_comment.text:
How to evaluate religious claims about the origin of the universe.

Take the big bang theory. It's a scientific theory. It was first seriously 
proposed/hypothesized in the early 1900's. In about 100 years we've gone 
from first serious considerations to an amazing amount of data that 
supports the big bang theory. It explains the evidence, it makes many 
predictions, and of the predictions we've been able to test, they are 
accurate, in some cases amazingly accurate. They predict things that no had 
ever observed before, and when the theory told them what they should look 
for, sure enough it turns out that those predicted effects were there for 
anyone to measure.

Now take the creationist claims (it's not a theory) about the origins of 
the universe. It was probably first proposed around 100,000 years ago, and 
it was expressed in oral traditions or writing more than 3,000 years ago. 
The Christian version of the creation myth (a myth that is common to almost 
all religions) began about 2,000 years ago.

The creationists have had 2,000 years to hone their logic. They've had all 
that time to marshal their arguments, to test their claims against the 
evidence, to polish up and present the very best case they can possibly 
make for the gods having conjured the universe from nothing.

Any of you feel like you are getting 2,000 years worth of finely honed, 
well tested logic when the creationists stumble in here and say "Oh yeah? 
Well fuck your evidence, I have magic book that tells me how the universe 
was created, that if the sun stops orbiting the Earth then the day will get 
longer, that unicorns were real (seriously, it's in the bible, read it), 
that bats are birds, that rabbits chew cud, and that the Earth is flat" 
(just ask Daniel who had a tower so tall he could see all "four corners" of 
the Earth)

Every single claim that religious books make about the natural world is not 
just wrong, it's fantastically, insanely, 
you've-got-to-be-fucking-kidding-me out in the left field babbling idiocy 
wrong. For exapmle, the bible and the quran both claim that the stars are 
little lights embedded in a metal hemisphere, with the quran going on to 
claim that stars sometimes fall to Earth and are quenched in the ocean.

Okay, I'm shooting fish in a barrel. Let's ignore the fundamentalist wacko 
claims and consider the "modern" mainstream religious claims of magical 
creation, the conjuring of the universe from nothing by invisible gods.

Okay, invisible gods conjuring a universe from nothing... whut? Seriously? 
We have a theory that explains the motion of the galaxies, that predicts 
the relative abundances of light elements in the universe, that predicts 
the cosmic microwave background and for which there isn't a single bit of 
evidence that seriously refutes the theory... and then we have a claim that 
some invisible gods magicked the universe into place.

2,000 fucking years they've had. They are presenting are the very *best* 
arguments that the very *brightest* minds from *every* country in the world 
where there religion is practiced.

You generally don't see all the ancillary evidence supporting the big bang 
theory presented or discussed because of the overwhelming nature of the 
biggest evidence to support it, but there are many smaller bits of 
supporting evidence. You can seek it out, read about it, look at the 
evidence and test it for yourself.

+Dammer DT  I think if you look back at my posting history you'll find that 
I never insulted anyone who simply stated they were religious. The insults 
and derision are reserved for anyone who makes statements of fact that are 
in clear denial of all the available evidence, which all religion based 
claims clearly are.

Having faith is one thing. Abandoning faith for belief is another. A person 
who has faith doesn't need evidence, and they don't pretend that their own 
personal faith represents physical/object reality for other people. James 
Carse does his usual wordplay with those concepts in "The Religious Case 
Against Belief" and it's an idea worth remembering.

The people who show up in discussion forums to claim that their personal 
belief in magic translates to reality for all are not religious, because 
they clearly lack faith. https://duckduckgo.com/?q=define+faith "n. Belief 
that does not rest on logical proof or material evidence."

To claim that the gods made the universe moves clearly from the subjective 
realm of faith/religion (unfounded beliefs) into the objective realm of 
evidence based reality.

Yeah, science *is* awesome and cool but it's also the *only* hope for the 
long-term survival of our species. It is only through science that we have 
advanced the human condition so much in the last few hundred years, and all 
the evidence is that only science can get us through the next few hundred 
years.

Timothy Ferris "The Science of Liberty" does a reasonably good job of 
explaining why science is absolutely necessary to ensure that liberal 
democracies continue to flourish. It's the only way out of the hole that 
religion and politics dug for us over the last 10,000 years or so.

The quality of life of every future generation depends on human beings 
accepting that the evidence talks and the bullshit walks - no matter who 
made the claim/who proposed the theory, if the testable evidence 
contradicts the claim/theory, then the claim/theory is false/wrong. Period. 
No exceptions for religious affiliations, no bending the rule for political 
affiliations, no changing the rules for particularly lucrative industries, 
no clinging on to failed theories no matter how famous or popular the 
scientist(s) who presented them.

It's *all* about the evidence. Anyone pretending that religious myths count 
as "evidence" or that a claim made not only without any evidence to support 
it, but such that no evidence could ever possibly be presented to support 
it, gets the ridicule and derision they deserve for fucking with the 
quality of life for every future generation on the planet.

It's awesome, it's cool, and it's also the *only* proven way to improve the 
future of every little kid you see walking down the street, or in your 
house, or at prayer services in your mosque.

outside the scope of the theory.

bang, because the theory doesn't describe where the big bang singularity 
came from. This is compounded by MinutePhysics which spouts unsupported 
speculation about the singularity and what might have happened before the 
singularity. This is the type of cutesy story that MinutePhysics loves, but

accepted theory of cosmology.

travelling. If the universe is expanding then the photon's wavelength gets 
longer, and so it changes 

http://www.google.co.uk/imgres?imgurl=http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/cf/EM_Spectrum_Properties_edit.svg&imgrefurl=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electromagnetic_spectrum&h=173&w=292&tbnid=s_XLa0EGsBiIgM:&zoom=1&tbnh=118&tbnw=199&usg=__eV_054JUKBoMC80RuxxPn-WMwsQ=&docid=Jt7TXMCR3fnp6M&itg=1&sa=X&ei=u0E3U6vIGMWO7QaTnIG4Aw&ved=0CJ0BEPwdMAo

and becomes more like an infra*red* rather than ultraviolet. This is 
redshift. We expect certain stars to emit light of specific frequencies, 
called the emission spectrum. And so we can see that the expected emission 
spectrum is shifted in wavelength towards the red usually, which means the 
light has expanded, grown longer, as it has travelled through space, 
suggesting the space has expanded too. Some stars though are blue shifted 
and so are coming towards us

captions.text:
Physicists used to think that the universe
had existed forever, unchangingly, because

that's what their observations of the night
sky suggested. Needless to say, this view

clashed with the "origin" or "creation" stories
of most major religions, which hold that the
universe had a beginning.

So it's not surprising that it was a Catholic
priest, Georges Lemaître, who was one of

the first major proponents of a new scientific
viewpoint - that the universe DID have a beginning.

Lemaître, of course, was also an excellent
mathematician and scientist and based this

conviction not (just) on his religious beliefs
but upon new experimental evidence from Edwin

Hubble that showed the universe was expanding.
This evidence, combined with the mathematics

of general relativity allowed Lemaître to
"rewind" cosmic history and calculate that

the farther back in time you go, the smaller
the universe had to be. The natural conclusion

is that everything we can currently see in
the universe was at one point in time more

or less at one point in space. Lemaître called
this idea the "primeval atom", but of course
today we know it as "the big bang theory".

Except "big bang" is a horrible name - it
would be much more accurate to call it "the

everywhere stretch". Because one of the most
common misconceptions about the big bang is

that it implies that the entire universe was
compressed into a single point from which

it then somehow expanded into the surrounding...
nothingness? It is true that the observable

universe, that is, the part of the whole universe
we can see from earth, WAS indeed shrunk down

to a very very small bit of space, but that
bit of space was NOT a single point, nor was

the rest of the Universe also in that same
bit of space.

The explanation for this is the magical power
of infinity. The whole universe is really

big - current data show it's at least 20 times
bigger than the observable universe, but that's

just a lower bound - it might be infinite.
And if you have an infinite amount of space,

you can scale space down, shrink everything
to minuscule proportions, and still have an

infinite amount of space. Kind of like how
you can zoom out as much as you want from

a number line, but it'll still be an infinite
number line.

Essentially, space doesn't need anywhere to
expand "into" because it can expand into itself

and still have plenty of room. In fact, this
is possible even if space turns out not to

be infinite in size, though the reasons are
complicated and have to do with the infinite
differentiability of the metric of spacetime...

But anyway, the event unfortunately known
as the big bang was basically a time, long

ago, when space was much more squeezed together,
and the observable universe, that is, everything

that we see from earth, was crammed into a
very very small piece of space. Because the

ENTIRE early universe was dense and hot everywhere,
spacetime was curved everywhere and this curvature

manifested itself as a rapid expansion of
space throughout the universe. And although

people call this "the big bang", it wasn't
just big, it was everywhere. And it wasn't

really an explosion - it was space stretching
out. It's really quite unfortunate that "the

Everywhere Stretch" isn't nearly as catchy
as "the Big Bang".

Which brings us to the "big bang singularity",
which is an even horribler name because every

single word is misleading. I mean, "singularity"
seems to imply something that happened at

a single point. Which isn't at all what it's
referring to - it SHOULD be called "the part

of the Everywhere Stretch where we don't know
what we're talking about." Basically, our

current physical models for the universe are
unable to properly explain and predict what

was happening at the very very beginning when
the universe was super SUPER scaled down.

But rather than call it the "time when we
don't have a clue what was happening, ANYWHERE",
for some reason we call it a "singularity".

This ignorance, however, does conveniently
answer the question What happened BEFORE the

big bang? Because it tells us the question
isn't well defined - back when space was so

incredibly compressed and everything was ridiculously
hot and dense, our mathematical models of

the universe break down SO MUCH that "time"
doesn't even make sense. It's kind of like

how at the north pole, the concept of "north"
breaks down - I mean, what's north of the

north pole? The only thing you can say is
that everywhere on earth is south of the north

pole, or similarly everywhen in the universe
is after... the beginning.

But once time began, whenever that was, space
expanded incredibly quickly all throughout

the universe - for a little while. Then expansion
slowed, the universe cooled, stuff happened,
and after a few billion years, here we are.

One thing we still DON'T know is why this
Everywhere Stretching happened - that is,

why did the universe start off in such a funny,
compressed state, and why did it follow the

seemingly arbitrary laws of physics that have
governed its expansion and development ever
since?

For Georges Lemaître, this might be where
God finally comes into the picture to explain

the things science can't. Except that experimental
evidence doesn't actually rule out the possibility

that there may indeed be a time "before" the
beginning, a previous age of the universe

that ended when space collapsed in on itself,
getting quite compressed and dense and hot,

but not enough to mangle up our ideas of what
time is. It would have then bounced back out,

stretching in a fashion similar to what we
call the big bang, but without the "we don't

know what we're talking about" singularity
part. So, physics may actually be nudging

us back to the view that the Universe is eternal
and didn't begin after all. In which case

Professor Lemaître might have to rethink
his interpretation of the words "in the beginning."

title: Science, Religion, and the Big Bang
